If you dont already know this anime is the first part of an ongoing series, and so far its very good. From Kadokawa the makers of many great anime titles such as: Heavens Lost Property, Spice and Wolf, Steins Gate, Deadman Wonderland, Ect. This anime is a great step forward from the typical anime concerning videogame life, Rather then showing the struggles of getting out of said game or trying to live a new life; The main character shows that he will be continuing the life style he has always had online. This Brings out the great concept of not just adapting or forcing tolive in a new worlds but shows how one would move on.

  The over all story and characters are good, however the art is not perfect. There is CG in some areas of the plot mainly during fight scenes, and the sounds and voices and sometimes get annoying but not overly. However the regular animation is something to be marveled, this improves the anime as a whole quite a bit.


Over all I like the feel of this anime and i believe that the second season will be worth watching as well. i would give this an 8/10.

This is one of those 'real people trapped in an MMO' anime, which isn't new. However, I think the series shines with depicting the experience of a guy who's stuck around for maybe a little too long, to the point where his guildmates have all stopped playing. He's not really the most socially intelligent guy, but he's got the gear and the game knowledge to accomplish his goals with his allies.
The story is a bit slow and the art isn't super original looking, but I think it captures a generic MMO environment sort of ok. If you haven't played MMOs long enough to have beenin the same situation as the main character you probably won't appreciate Overlord as much since he's kind of the redeeming factor in an otherwise average anime.

A popular MMORPG is shut down one evening after a higher ranking magic users dismay behind the guild of great wealth and prestige all dissolve as the responsibilities of life occur. With a small fortune, nigh-limitless ability and a devoted team of subordinates to do?
Overlord spins the tail of a man trapped in the world of an MMORPG with a fantastic spin from the likes of other popular shows including sword art online. Thrust into the thick of the show, Momonga, distressed at first, wastes no time fondling a large breasted NPC, equipping the worlds best armor set and exploring the new world with God-Tierability.


Imagine having access to all end-game items in a popular MMORPG then the servers reset everyone to beginner levels except you. Momonga, as the plot demands, has no friends, family or electric bill as  he spends countless hours in the world he refers is similar to Yggdrasil. Other non-playable characters now have a pulse, distinct personalities and voice actors that put the previous game to shame -- they also have complete trust and faith that their lord Momonga is God and will throw down their lives as guardians to the success and glory of the power wizard.


Competing in the new game world as a magic caster with the ability to swap into world class items, armors and wield weapons outside of his class -- Yggdrasil or the new world Momonga resides in functions similar to FFXIV. With a swap of a few weapons, Momonga 'equips' the class but none of the classes passive abilities. Playing the game with the mindset of a magic caster, this causes some concerns as he lacks adequate skill as a martial-arts fighter or swordsman. 


Momonga is a fast-learner, attuning to the otherwise world shattering realization that everyone he knew -- now aspiring to become decent members of society are long gone and the terrifying fact that he is alone in this world yields not a single hesitation nor concern at all. Momonga passively meanders on, adopting the role as any good role-player of the benevolent ruler in his castle. 


Overlord gained popularity as a light-novel then manga series of similar length. I ran through 10 chapters, hungering for more when I noticed the entirety of the show was available. Now with the first 13 episodes highlighting the overall tone of the manga --- I find an irresistible desire to advance the show by any means. Where the manga shines in its adherence to Momonga slow evolution to the position of 'overlord', the anime is the cliff-notes to both written materials. 


If any complaints to the story is the complete lack of weight to the actions. While Momonga is in fact 'alive' in the 'world' , the inclusion of Yggdrasil as the basis in all his understanding plays tribute to Sword Art Online. Unlike Sword Art Online, Overlord advances without a true urgency or sense of consequence that encourages the more scrutinizing fan to question all of the decisions Momonga makes throughout the show. On the other side -- many fans of anime are flocking to Overlord for the complete disregard of consequence that overshadowed Sword Art Online. With a man with nigh infinite ability and wealth, will we see the making of a final boss NPC integrated into a direct sequel of Momonga's favorite MMORPG? The first season is introductory and fans of the manga may remark at the lack of scene for scene adaption of the source material, but Overlord has good pacing and an addictive cast. 


Here is hoping the second season will come sooner rather than later.

This show has an intelligent plot, a proven-to-work exciting setting, is full of character, has atmospheric animation and is overall a great change to the ordinary overused everything-i-just-mentioned.
All of it's flaws that i can come up with could easily be 'fixed' with a little more budget (holds true to many anime, but some anime are just plain dumb no matter how much cash you throw at it).
Some people might compare this with SAO or the like, which makes sense since they could be grouped into the same 'niche' genre, but i have seen some people call this rip-off that and that... which makes about asmuch sense as saying that all spy movies are rip-off of James Bond (mind you, James Bond was not the first of it's kind, neither was SAO).\n\n
This show is close to being a masterpiece, i have a hard time putting my finger on exactly what it is that keeps it from a 10, the conclusion of the series wasen't really a conclusion at all, overall in general it's hard to give something 10 that hasen't finished. A season 2 would be much appreciated.

Overlord is based on a series of light novels by Maruyama Kugane. The anime version came out last year and was produced by Madhouse. Going into this one, about all I know is the basic premise and that opinions are a bit divided on the series. So, let's take a look and I'll put in my pfennig.
Story:
In the distant future, virtual reality gaming is a thing and it's given rise to a new breed of MMORPGs, which allow the users to immerse themselves in the game worlds. Our story takes place with a popular game, Yggdrasil, entering the end of its life-span and shutting downits servers.In spite of having strong tech to back it up it was published by EA so it was only a matter of time before terrible business practices did it in. That is my head canon explanation for that. Anyway, on the last day of the servers running, Momonga, a man with no life, is reflecting on all the good times he had with his guild mates before they quit playing. He watches the clock tick down but stays online, determined to enjoy the game until the last moment. The day finally rolls over and, much to his surprise, he's still in the game. Not only that, but the NPCs that he and his former comrades made are displaying personalities and Nazarick, his guild base, has been transported into unfamiliar territory that still seems to follow game logic.


This opens up a lot of interesting story possibilities about how this happened and what's happening with Momonga's body. Is this still a game that his brain has somehow become trapped in, has he just lost his mind and been lost in delusions of the only thing he cares about or is it some kind of other dimension, one that he unwittingly helped create, that he was able to cross into? There are so many possibilities. The series then proceeds to toss that little plot point to the wayside and not really bring it up. Well, that seems a waste. But it's fine, there's another compelling story angle they could go with here, since Momonga and his NPC comrades are all monsters of various kinds. Stories about antagonists and/or beastly groups can be really good. Except that they don't really do anything with that either. About the biggest impact it has is that they present themselves as humans and do some things that are semi-villainous. But that's fine too. The NPCs keep bringing up the way they were created by Momonga's comrades and that could be a really interesting angle from a philosophical standpoint & from a narrative, “how exactly is this working?” stand point. Except that they don't do anything with that either. How do you have elements that could lead to three different strong stories and not take advantage of any of them?


That may be the biggest flaw with the series. It doesn't properly take advantage of any of its potentially fascinating story ideas. The second biggest issue is a matter of tension. It's established early on that Momonga is absurdly powerful when compared to the people/NPCs of this world. Not only that, but it's established that he has ways to resurrect people who die. Which means that there's no reason for us, as the audience, to be concerned about him or the other major characters.


That being said, there are some areas where I will give the series credit. The world building is quite good and, to be completely fair, they're clearly setting up for a sequel so it's entirely possible that the more compelling aspects of the story do get better built on in the later material. As such, I can't really fault the series for prioritising the world building in the early stuff. Of course, that's also assuming that they do give us more of the interesting aspects. I haven't read the light novels so, for all I know, they may still be unaddressed after nine volumes.


Characters:


The characters are pretty under-developed in this. On one hand, you can somewhat understand it since this series focuses on the world building. However, we really need strong characters in a series like this where the main protagonist is so over-powered. We need compelling characters to keep our interest and all this series gives us is characters who might become interesting at some point.


Art:


The art is actually pretty strong with creative designs for a lot of Nazarick's guardians and action sequences that are really good. There are some designs that are quite typical, but it also makes sense given the context.


Sound:


The voice acting is pretty passable but also standard. Hino Satoshi's performance as the lich, Momonga, is a bit odd and seems out of place. However, he's also a regular person in a video game skin. As such it works to have his voice be a bit out of place for the character. The music is pretty good.


Ho-yay:


The series doesn't really have any ho-yay.


Final Thoughts:


What Overlord ultimately gives us is potential. There's potential for a compelling narrative. There's the potential for interesting characters. As the first series in a longer franchise, it's not a bad introduction. That being said, the series also isn't good. Maybe if it gets renewed for a second series, that one will be. As is, it's pretty mundane. The main protagonist is too powerful for the series to have any real tension. The good ideas haven't been developed, nor have the characters and the voice acting is just standard. Overall, I give it a 5/10. Next week, I'll take a look at Kannazuki no Miko.

MMOs, SAO, power fantasies, Over-powered protagonist, RPGs/JRPGs. If you enjoy any of the previous items, then more likely than not you will enjoy Overlord. Bam, there you have it. Now you can go watch the show without having to finish my review. Now for those who are still here, I'll let you in on a secret. This show is neither good, nor bad; in fact this show is just about average. The story details the start of Momonga's (Ainz Ooal Gown) eventual development towards... wait a minute..... I actually don't know, seeing as how the show never really tells you what his final goal is.Anyway, that's fine, Momonga is the main character; a real person who has now been trapped in the game that he was once an avid fan of. Is this a dream come true, or is this a nightmare from which he will never awaken. Is this show truly as bad as people say it is? Is it as good as some say it is? Buckle up because it’s going to be a long ride, now, allow me to answer all of your quandaries.


==Spoilers Galore in this Review==


Characters: 6

Character Development: 5

I look at the other reviews of this show and I see people who are either swayed too much by their enjoyment of the show (and there is nothing wrong with that, you enjoy a show and are more than right to share said opinion with others), and people who are overly critical of the show. This show is not bad. Let me just get that out there. Now allow me to continually bash this show for the next few paragraphs, this one especially.

This show is like SAO in that they both have people trapped in a game, otherwise Overlord is like tacky knock off of the original (Now I am by no means saying that SAO is amazing, I will be reviewing that show tomorrow in order to provide a follow up to this review). This show is terrible when it comes to characters, this show manages to not have a single well fleshed out character, and little to no development among the characters or with themselves. Let's start with the main character, Momonga; initially we are introduced to a character who we know nothing about save for the fact that he is now trapped in Yggdrasil (the MMO world), now this would be fine if he were to have a character archetype that was built upon based off of the difficulties he faces in this new world. But there are no real physical challenges that he can be faced with seeing as how he is so overpowered. Then that only leaves us with the possibility of metaphysical character or emotional character development, the first never really happens seeing how he never seriously questions how he ended up in that world or anything along those lines; which leaves us with the final option, emotional development. Even emotional development doesn't really happen, there are only a few moments where he comes close to something similar, and the closest case was the whole fiasco with Shalltear Bloodfallen where he has to take on the heavy task of killing one of his own friends. However the sadness is only momentary as he proceeds to revive her moments later, taking away from any form of development he may have had do go through in order to cope with his actions. Moving on to the other characters they all face basically the same problems; Albedo is a plain character who was literally programmed to like the main character for no reason, making any sense of romance in the show seem meaningless (this also manages to make me not really care for the actual possible romance between Nfirea Bareare and Emmot). All of the character follow some sort of stereotype and bring nothing new to the table (Gothic loli, large breasted rival of loli, weirdo that no one likes, butler, cross-dressing twins, ...), and half of these characters seem as if they were pandering to some sort of fetishist, making me have even less respect for each individual character. All in all its just a massive cast of lack luster characters who are all forgettable, none of which undergo any form of interesting development which helps push forward the story. Easily the weakest point of this anime.

Plot: 6

Pacing: 7

When it comes to plot, this show is once again kind of lacking, while it’s not as bad as the previous section it still doesn’t really redeem itself in this category. The story starts off and it doesn’t really grab your attention, as you are greeted to not just one but several first episodes that are full of dialogue and monologue. While these speeches do serve to introduce us to the world and what is happening, it is done so slowly and poorly. Looking back now there is little to no action in the first few episodes, and that is where this show truly shines, its beautifully well done animation, its well-choreographed fighting scenes, and fun action sequences. Fortunately the show doesn’t bore you at first, so once you manage to dredge your way through the beginning muck you finally get to the meat of the show. In my opinion the middle of the show is the only time that it really got my attention. It was around the introduction of Nfirea that the story took a turn and started to introduce more grim elements into the story, and while I feel that this anime could not evolve into a “mature” themed show, due to its own simplicity, I did enjoy some true feelings of despair being conveyed as opposed to the aloof sadness that Momonga displays regarding his being trapped in this world. The show starts out slower than most, but that can be overlooked as it does pick up after a little bit. It would have fared better if it had more episodes to work off of; that is assuming that they took advantage of said episodes and spread out the show more evenly, all the while explaining and developing characters more.

Music: 8

Animation: 9

Finally I can write about an area of the show I very much so enjoyed, its music and animation, let’s start with the music. If you’ve heard both the ED and the OP, then you know what I’m talking about, the Ed is a fun song, however the OP is an awesome head banging fun time. Not just the intro and outro song should be mentioned though as Gou Fumihiroki did an excellent job coordinating the music with the fights, and even the battle music matches the situations quite well. All that complimented by the animation, which while not striving to be different from most mainstream anime still does a nice job matching up well with the fantasy theme of the show. It is in my opinion that Madhouse’s animation style is perfectly suited for the fantasy genre, with its well emphasized magic animations, and aesthetically pleasing bright color pallet, which in this show is often contrasted nicely with darker yet still fluorescent colors.

Enjoyment: 7

Did I enjoy this show: meh. Will you enjoy this show: sure? Who knows until you watch and finish it; it is my belief that you cannot label a show a failure until you have finished it. Similarly to how you can’t claim a show to be the best ever until you have seen a vast amount of not just anime, but literature, cinema, and other forms of media as well. This show did not impress me, and I may have had to push myself to continue it at first, however in the end my opinion of the show changed from a 6/10 to almost a 7/10 (Now it must be noted that 7/10 is average, so it’s not a bad score, nor is it a good score) just because I managed to get through the crummy beginning.

I have been writing this review for over two hours now, and I am done, so I will stop here. I hope you enjoyed reading my work as it took a lot of time and thought to write. When all is said and done we’re all good friends in the end and shouldn’t fight vehemently over our differing opinions, instead we should provide feedback on what we disagree on and what we liked. Speaking of which, if you have any desire to do so, feel free to give me any advice regarding my writing style, any advice for improvements, comments, or questions. I hope you all have a wonderful rest of your day.

______________________________________________________________________________

Final Verdict 68/100

This is gonna be my first review so ill just get it started.
You ever get tired of characters that don't wanna kill or have too many morals? well now you have Overlord. His goal is to take spread his name and he's not afraid to dirty his hands to do it. While the theme of being stuck in a game has been done before this time he doesn't really seem to care. In fact he seems to spend about 2 minutes total considering how to leave then decides it's not so bad.
Part of the reason i loved this anime was because sometimes you just wanta super overpowered mc that just pulls out skill after skill and seems super badass. And with overlord since he's sort of a bad guy too he can actually use skills that kill people not just knock them unconscious or something dumb like that.\n\n
But besides the fighting it's also interesting to see how they analyze the new world and come up with strategies and tactics and are able to exploit everything around them. It definately has a tton of action in it but at the same time they try to make the mc both super powerful and really adept at planning and tactics.\n\n
Overall I found this really enjoyable because I mean how often do you get a super badass overpowered bad guy main character stuck in a game mix up?

I got so much enjoyment out of this. It wasn't a perfect season by any means, but it sure was a lot of fun. OP hero is OP.
While watching I found myself asking a lot of questions: How did Ainz/Momonga get stuck in the game? Why? How far can their group take it and kick ass? 
I also found myself intrigued and at the same time rooting for the MC to win.
I loved the cast of characters—Nabe, Cocytus, Aura and Mare, the whole gang. They're all so different, but unique in their own way.
In terms of pacing, they took so much time to craft thefirst half, that I felt like the second half dragged a little in comparison. I can't put my finger of it, but it didn't feel like a whole lot happened, and that it was only starting to scratch the surface of the story.\n

Here's the point of the show;
You're the best of the best, you're skilled intellectually and physically, you've got bragging rights, you've got unfaltering support from friends and family, you own all the land and money.
Holy shit man, you have it all.
Well, that's what our MC is and has.
Made possible by being one of the best players in a virtual online video game world, when it was time when the game was going to be pulled from its plug, our MC stayed to the very end.
Except he never left, the world never left, in fact he is the only one left.
Left with all that he hadmade, owned, built, and bonded.\n
Now what is left but to continue doing so?\n\n
This show heavily appeals to gamers, particularly in the MMORPG demographic or those who are fans of fantasy worlds. That usually goes hand in hand though.\n\n
Beside their focused appeal tactics for their target audience, they actually have some rather pretty and effective visuals, characters, and world.\n\n
It certainly isn't a disney world, it shows off its grit but it also shows it has a scenic route for our characters to journey through. The characters themselves each have their own unique traits that make then lovable.\n\n
But ho' boy, the stuff in the world and what they do in the world. It's pretty damn cool, its one of the biggest reasons why Virtual Reality is pushed in the gaming business.\n\n
Imagine seeing things from real life that you never thought you would witness, or imagination that you could've never perceived yourself!\n\n
Give this one a shot, I might have oversold this one admittedly, but I do think it is quite awesome to see, not just as a show but as a story world.

Ever wondered how the second Arc of Sword Art Online 1 would be without Asuna? No? Well bad luck, because here you go: Watch Momonga, an OP MC beeing trapped within an RPG-like world, with no actual goal and nothing that presents even the slightes challenge to him.
Also watch him contradict himself and unlike one would expect from the title: never beeing or even trying to be an actual Overlord.
If this would be an anime about an evil Lich trying to conquer the world, it would be fun. If it was another Isekai with and OP-MC who is trying to learn about the world andfinding his place while building his mandatory harem, also nice. If it would be about someone, who find himself in a new world, has to learn the rules and faces actual challenges, all could be nice and good.


Instead watch the OP-MC, who already knows all the rules of the world, trying to progress without any actual goal, so the writers can try to give him as many contradictions as possible, to have it both ways in any way. Don't forget his love-interest sidekick, who is attractive, designed to love him and made me ask for the first time in all anime I know "Why doesn't he have sex with her?"


My main issue is the story:

We follow Momonga, a nerd who played a SAO-RPG which is about to be shut down. He is the leader of the strongest guild in the game, he himself is the strongest player, the guild still exists with OP NPC guards as well. However instead of shutting down, the game somehow transports him and his guild to another world, where he suddenly is trapped, the NPC come alife and Momonga is... just there.

Momonga finds himself in this new world and with no actual goal. The entire plot is driven by him trying to get known so he could figure out if other player are also transported there - why he wants to know that and what he is going to do once he knows? Who cares, here see him beeing OP agan. The best way to do this, seems to join a guild, try to get a high rank, while at the same time keeping a low profile. Now one might wonder: How can one try to become known as one of the strongest warriors, while also avoiding showing strength? And that is a good question, which the show quite frankly ignores. The MC will at one point try to act normal and make others think he is just a bit stronger, then he will go forth and enslave beasts considered some kind of god or fight an undead army all by himself. You know, low profile stuff.

Also while he does want to make his name known, to propably find others from the old game, he also changes his name and never mentions the name of his old guild - because that somehow helps.


So the story doesn't go anywhere and neither do the characters. The NPC are shown to having a personality designed by the guild and they are also totally OP and have pretty bland characters designs. So they don't get anywhere with a characters arc.

Neither does Momonga, of whom we don't even learn, if he considers other people in the wold as actual people or just NPC. One could think he is transforming into the actual skeleton-overlord his avatar is, because he is super easy on inoocent getting killed or even killing them himself. However when it comes to his guild, he suddenly shows emotions like shame. Which made me ask, why the heck does he have natural emotions towards characters, which he knows as actual mindless NPCs, but not towards all the other people in this new world, which he doesn't know anything about, including if they are thinking, feeling beeings?


Now we have a story that doesn't go anywhere and characters who don't develope in any way or even seem to know what they are actually thinking. Now let's look at the delivery as well. Obviously, since Momonga is not an evil Wizzard, but a RPG-player from another game, he is reacting to the world by comparing it to his old. Which means narrating about spells and monsters and levels and mechanics, so we always know, why he is superior to everything presented.

But beware, exposition-dump narration is not the worst thing, the show is offering to show us the world, no that  my friend, it is pointless buffing. You know buffs? Spells people use to strengthen their stats? The new world also contains buffing-spells and everytime they are used, we have characters uttering some spells and after that, do stuff, without giving a point of referrence to understand, what has changed. As someone who knows games, one can make out what those buffs will most likely do. However without a point of referrence on how the fight would go down without the buff, this is just pointless timewasting. It is just a plattform for the writers to show they can make up names for buffs or spells in general - as we are never presented some kind of magical-system or how certain spells actually change the outcome of a fight, it doesn't have any impact.


But the worst part and which shows best at the very end (so spoilers ahead) is how the show actually tries to raise the stakes:

Since the MC and his guild are only OP-characters know, the only hard fight the MC can have, is against his own minions, which happens at the end without any buildup (because that would need character developement). To know the stakes are high, we are shown an item which is said to be super-powerfull. Oh but it doesn't work. So let's get some items which are even more powerfull. Got that? Good. Now don't bother explaining what any of them do or if they are even used in the actual fight. With that out of the way, let's also use a couple of buffs without giving any referrence on what they do, use some super-powerfull spells, which where never mentioned before and no idea how they work and ofcourse a couple of new items which do stuff and make some kind of juxtaposition but acting like they are cheap or whatever but totally usefull.

All set and done? Now tell give us more exposition on why Momonga wins this fight with some more tactics around stuff, that was never mentioned before.


And in case that finale is not worse: after the fight Momonga is known to be powerfull beyond imagination - the one thing he tried to avoid...

Oh but now we know there are others who might have some of the super-super-powerfull items, which can do "stuff" and work "somehow".

Ok, this show is not meant to be a cerebral experience. It does not have a weighty philosophy or ethical dilemma or even a who-dun-it atmosphere. It is not a meticulous character study or a depiction of humanity. It is a liberating experience for all the MMORPG lovers that brings out their inner God complex vicariously. It does tug and scrape at your conscience (intentionally) to reveal the true nature of this God complex. The protagonist is a leader of bad guys. He is an average human gamer thrust into this role of this supreme overlord. Well, as most RPG gamers can relate, we allseek to achieve such a powerful status while killing all the minions and sacrificing NPCs to gain levels. 


Story: 7


As Momonga, the protagonist starts adjusting to his new life as the Ovrelord, he feels himself losing his humanity gradually. The people in the new world are all just pawns for extending his power and understanding of the unfamiliar place nad its potential. His actions become more calculated and cautious like that of a Mob boss.


We don't really know much about the NPCs who get slain by our characters in the games and so we don't mind slaying them. But in here , the show gives us deep insights into their background and struggles they face in their life up until the point they get killed by the protagonists. This show illustrates how video games subtly desensitize us to violence. To Momonga, the people are pawns he needs to improve his power in a video game while we as viewers feel empathetic to their life and the situation which makes it harder for us to actually root for the protagonist. I like the fact that the story has these neat layers to it instad of devolving into a rambling tale of easy conquest of a supreme overlord.


World Building: 9


This show has is a visual and visceral treat for all fantasy lovers. From the magic system to different races inhabiting the world it simply is breathtaking. It resembles a MMORPG game very much in this aspect and it is glorious. The scope for further development is infinite due to the same reason.


Art and Animation: 10


Splendid! Madhouse is as outstanding as ever in this department. I loved every frame and every design (well give or take a few). I couldn't help admiring how beautiful the art and animation was especailly during the battle scenes


Sound: 7


It's alright. Nothing that really stands out although it is composed to suit the atmosphere very well.  Occasionally, there are a few good scores which nicely complement the beautiful visuals



Characters: 8


What can I say either you like em or you don't. The characters are, at a first glance, pretty simple and one dimensional ( save a few). HOWEVER they are damn interesting and enjoyable and subtly grow over the episodes. It is like observing NPC in the games starting to evolve gradually as they learn and adapt from theri experiences in the new world. I believe this is also one of the aspects of the story that the author aims to address as we see Momonga constantly making observations on how his subordinates change over time.


My one gripe is that most of the female characters were portrayed as evil, manipulative or bitchy. Some even looked a lot alike with blond hair. Almost all of them are smitten by Momonga. I wish the author had included some variety in his character design for the girls department instead of making the anime look like a cheap harem show.


Conclusion:


I really enjoy this show from the first episode in Season 1 to the latest one. I could hardly stop binging on all the episodes. This might not be for people who are easily put off by overpowered protagonist with an evil side. The show does not dwell on the MC being morally conflicted by his actions or longing for his past life (which makes sense given he lost a part of his humanity) It does deliver fully on the entertainment scale with every developing event piquing our interest.


If you liked Hellsing Ultimate, Berserk or even One-Punch Man, do pick this one up without hesitation

Spoiler free section: The writing in this show is terrible and the author is clearly a hack. The characters are totally unrealistic and only behave in evil ways so they can have the maximum shock value. The characters in this show were clearly designed by a 12 year old edgelord and behave to be as edgy as possible with no regard for their setting or personalities. Skip this show. If you want to see a well written mmo anime watch Log Horizon or The King's Avatar.
Spoiler section (not just for season 1 but some things from the following seasons as well):
The main character is anormal person with a boring job and no known desires to kill or torture any real people or game characters. He is the last remaining member of what was once the greatest guild in a dead mmorpg that is being shut down. He finds himself transported into another world as his game character with his guild's base and npc characters brought to life and turned into actual living and free thinking beings. At this point I loved the show, amazing setting and world building and as these characters are at max power they are all basically gods in this world (although it takes them a little while to realize that) and it is incredibly fun to see what they will do with that power.


But then things quickly go downhill. In the first interaction he has with the new world he finds himself in he decides to save a village but not resurrect the people that died in the attack before he arrived even though it is easily within his power and if he wanted he could also erase the memories of the people that died and those that saw them die so no one would know he had this power. He could make a huge difference in the lives of these innocent people but instead chooses not to for no reason other than that he doesn't feel like it. That just isn't a good enough reason. So many cool things could have come from that, maybe those memories could come back at some point/be discovered by an enemy that captures someone from the village in the future, ect. A lot of cool things could have developed from this moment but instead nothing happens just to demonstrate how uncaring the main character is. This isn't a show ruiner but it was the first red flag.


Later he accompanies an adventuring group. A group of friends that band together and go on adventures just like the friends he used to have and lost and misses dearly. This new group is all killed after the adventure and he leaves them dead. Once again he can easily revive the dead and erase memories. He has the power to stop something in the past that traumatized him from occurring again but he chooses not to. (I'm told in the light novel he looked down on the party but in the anime he was friendly enough with them so the adaptations clearly differ and it is wrong to say that he should act the same way in every adaptation even if the events play out differently. The author also agrees because the actions he takes in the anime differ in places from the actions he takes in the light novels so this is clearly not a 1:1 translation of the light novel). Someone that has lost all their friends they used to adventure with and explore a world of mystery together with should see this happening and think "I have the power of a God now and this will never happen again" and bring those dead adventurers back to life. But he doesn't. They remind him of something he lost so his reactions should either be to protect them so he can feel like he protected his friends memories or he should feel like they are a pale imitation of his relationship with his friends and get angry at them for the perceived mockery of that bond. But instead he just shrugs it off. This is the moment the show was ruined for me. I've played a dying mmorpg and lost all my friends one by one. I am a borderline sociopath so I don't give a crap about most of what happens around me. But I would spit in the face of God if it would bring back even a small part of the fun times I used to have adventuring with my friends. The way this character behaves does not fit himself or his personality at all and that is why this show is terrible.


Yes he is a sociopath so he feels no emotions but allow me to phrase it like this: If you see a random object of no use to you lying around do you break that object? Just because you don't care about something doesn't mean you have a desire to destroy and get enjoyment from it. Some people just throw away paper plates when they are done with them and don't crush them up for the thrill of crushing something just because they can. Now imagine that paper plate was a plastic plate and had a picture on it that reminded you of something special to you. It would make a lot more sense for you to clean that plate and keep it when you were done instead of snapping it in half just because you're so cool and edgy. Not caring about something isn't the same as wanting to destroy everything. This author clearly thinks being a sociopath is cool and dark and that honestly isn't the case. Mental illnesses are not cool no matter what the media wants you to think. This is just another failing on the part of the author to display anything accurately. Not his characters, not mmorpg players, and not sociopaths. Everything is just how he wants it to be to satisfy his desire to show us evil characters acting like shitheads.


At the finale of season 1 the main character needs to fight against a npc guild member under mind control (The only challenge these characters have in this world is against each other because they are the only beings even close to the power level of the main character). And you get all excited because you finally get to see a serious fight using their mmorpg spells, items, and abilities. And how does the main character win the fight? He uses cash shop items that are stupidly overpowered and break the mechanics of the game. Do you know what real mmorpg players/gamers in general hate? God damn microtransactions that break their game. Selling game breaking items/xp to make money off the corpse of your game is sickening to anyone that actually loves the game and wants to have fun in it. No real mmo player would be like "oh boy gotta show off those cash shop items in my anime and have them be the main mechanics in how this fight is won". It's terrible.


Many other things continue to happen in later seasons as well. For example:


Even if you want to argue that those earlier adventurer group he watched die should have been left for dead because he didn't care about them the same way he cared about his actual friends/guild members one npc of his guild saved a human woman in need. The person that created this npc once saved the main character in the exact same way. Is the main character touched by these actions reminding him of his cherished friend he lost that once saved his life? Nope. He instead tortures the npc, dragging him in front of him and joking about having the girl killed before bringing the girl in and ordering the npc to kill her to prove his loyalty. That is not the actions the main character should have taken based on his background and personality. Once again the author clearly only cares about making him as edgy and cool as possible. It is dumb and written terribly.


Even if you want to argue that him threatening an npc is in character you can't because he previously revived the npc he had to fight at the end of season 1 and showed great concern for her. So not only do his actions not make sense based on his personality and backstory they also don't make sense based on the things he has previously done in the show. The author is clearly a terrible hack.


Later on a village of lizardmen are attacked, they all band together and the main character sees use in keeping them alive but he still kills a bunch of the village leaders who have the strongest abilities just to prove how edgy and cool he is even though this directly goes against the reason why he decided to recruit the lizardmen in the first place.


After that his base gets invaded by adventurers looking to loot the place and he personally kills a group of them that have bonds of friendship so strong all of them agree to band together and try to hold him off so a young female member of their party can escape. As you should expect none of this reminds him of his lost friends that he cherishes so deeply. He cares nothing for their teamwork and personally kills them all, except for the girl they let escape. He orders one of the npcs to kill her instead. (In the light novel she is kept alive and tortured).


All this show does is make you care for characters by showing off how much fun and adventure they have together and how strong their bonds of friendship are before torturing and killing them to show how cool and edgy the main character is. It's a terrible show and I can't suggest skipping it strongly enough.

Overlord. There is a lot of good things I can say about this anime. Just to let you know, this review is based on the every Overlord season. Yes, season one through three. First off, the plot. Just like your typical stuck in MMORPG animes, the main character Momonga also known as Ainz got stuck inside the game and can't get out. But unlike many stuck in games anime, the our main character is a antagonist. Also it's not the actual game that he got stuck inside, he's clan Ainz Ooal Gown has teleported to a another world. But soon later, Ainz asked himself "DoI really want to go back to the real world?" And that proofs that this anime is not a regular stuck in games type of anime.


The second thing I can say about this anime is the mysteries. I mean, it's good but, it takes too long for it to solved or the anime adaptation don't give us enough information about it. For example, at the beginning of the second season, there was two people talking about Shalltear and how they should react to it. When Bangaisekiji also known as Zesshi Zetsumei (that girl with white and black girl) asked Ishokkusekiji her and Shalltear who's stronger? Ishokkusekiji said "You". But there is a reason behind it but the anime didn't say it, and it gives us some important information.

This is the reason why he said yes. He compared the punch's between Shalltear and Bangaisekiji, and he knew that Shalltear was stronger. But Bangaisekiji had armors from the six gods and Shalltear didn't had any armor on. Or that's what Ishokkusekiji saw, of course Shalltear had the armor from Nazarick. But wow, a human is strong enough to win over Shalltear without armor. Even though she doesn't have any armor on, she's still the strongest floor guardian.


The third thing I can say about this anime is the character management. Unlike Mayoiga, we actually get background information, what they are capable of, and the meaning behind their names for every characters!  Although it's never mentioned, you can always see it by looking it up on Google. Now let's talk about the setting that the supreme being has put for the characters. When Sebas and Shalltear was talking inside the carriage, Sebas asked Shalltear why she's always fighting with Aura, she answered this "Actually, I don't think she's too bad but my creator Peroronchino chose me to act this way so I'm just doing what he said to do." This sentence explains that the character is slightly different from the setting that the supreme ones gave to them. And also, their pretty similar to their creators! For example the creator of Sebas, Touch me and the creator of Demiurge, Ulbert has a really crappy relationship and so does their creation!


The fourth thing I can say about this anime is anime is how author manages every characters.

Again, unlike Mayoiga (this is the last time I'm gonna compare this to Mayoiga I promise. I know these two animes have nothing in similar.) the author keeps a well track of every characters. For example, we even got to see what Hamusuke was doing when he was not with Ainz! And that's how you keep track a story with many characters. 


Last but not least, the score. Only one word can describe this anime for me, beautiful. I love the animation, characters, story, and the main character. This anime definitely earns a 10/10 from me. And it is my second favourite anime of all time.

I have a bias towards shows that fall under the stuck in a game genre, but even more so towards fantasy.  So please understand, I thoroughly enjoyed this show.
While the concept of being stuck in a game has been seen more frequently, I enjoyed the approach Overlord took.  In the past, all shows involved people becoming stuck in the game and the main goal is always survival and returning home.  Overlord took a different approach.  Sure anyone stuck in a game has hopes and desires to return to the real world, but it is definitely not the overarching theme in Overlord.Instead we find ourselves in a world where there might be nobody from the original game.  This allows us to learn about the, main character, the main character's friends and his former allies from the personalities of the floor guardians and every other NPC created by his guild.   The approach is different too because with his overwhelming power, the main character views the former NPCs more so as children and representations of his friends.  


For some people the blinding loyalty each floor guardian has towards the main character is extreme, but given the circumstances that he is the only remaining creator it is understandable where the NPC's are coming from.  It also can be hilarious, if you can relate to the concept of watching over and teaching children, for their arguments and decisions mirror the actions of loyal children.  Maybe too an extreme, but that ridiculous adds to the hilarity.  However, I can see this being one of the biggest obstacles for many people.  I believe that if your truly understand the situation and really think about the relationship between creator and created it adds a unique element to the story.  If you cannot do that I foresee many characters falling short of expectations for some.


The setting also sets the show apart as instead of the classic, fight, power level up we see across many animes, this setting the character is not only already extremely powerful, but he has a gigantic fortress and equally powerful allies right at the start.  This allows for a different avenue to learn about the world and a different lens through which we view the world. 


Overall I thoroughly enjoyed Overlord, laughed at the ridiculous comments made by the created, and enjoyed watching an overpowered mage dismantle the obstacles that appeared before him.  I would recommend Overlord to anyone who likes the fantasy genre (more so magic or undead) or the trapped in a game genre.  I myself found the show, and finished the 13th episode a few hours later.  Hopefully you will feel the same jubilation.

Overlord ! the anime that defined my Tuesday as "EPIC" , this anime if the kind of anime that you can watch an episode several times without getting bored, i will be divining by review into sections avoiding spoilers so enjoy reading ! :
1- Story : 9/10 :- The story is something fresh and unique, it follows the same aspect of many other MMO animes out there, expect that it does it right, a pretty excellent story that sets you on the edge., it's not set inside an MMORPG world, instead, certain guild is transported into a different world that is a real world wherepeople get killed without respawning.


2- Art : 10/10 :- The art in overlord is top notch, death is uncensored, and everything is very highly detailed, well, this was made by MH after all, so all that is to be expected.


3- Sound : 10/10 :- The opening and the ending songs are amazing ! , voice acting is descent, especially shalltear, and all voice actors played their role very well considering that they voice acted a somewhat evil characters.


4- Characters : 10/10 ! :- Oh boy the characters , the members of nazarick , especially the guardians, are extremely high quality, each of the guardians feels as if they can hold their grounds well as a final boss in any other high quality anime, and what i mean by that is that their design, background, acting, and everything else is top quality, and aside from the main characters, the villains do make you hate them, and the side characters are also pretty descent.


5-Enjoyment : 10/10 :- I don't remember the last time i was so excited each week to watch a certain anime, it's that unique feeling when you get your self prepared with snacks, turn on your AC, and set on waiting for it to be released, overlord made me remember that feeling, when i played each episode i kept rewinding some parts of it over and over again because of how much enjoyment i was feeling , the battles, the conversations between Ainz and the others, and everything is amazing.


Overall : 10/10 ! :- if you enjoy animes with badass main character and moments that always keeps you on the edge, then overlord is definitely worth checking out.

One would think that after so many anime revolving around similar concepts, something like Overlord is not going to bring anything new to the table.
Well, it has.
I was pleasantly surprised when Overlord offers a fresh angle on the whole 'trapped-in-a-virtual-reality' concept. The key difference in Overlord's setting that gives it uniqueness is this : The main character, Momonga is the only player in the new world, with the rest being 'NPCs'.
Why is this even important? 
It is important because it sets the foundation for Momonga's subsequent actions. It is important because it separates and elucidates 3 different viewpoints:
1. Momonga's viewpoint. To him everyone in thenew world are NPCs'; they are human and yet less than human to him.\n
2. The NPC's viewpoint. An NPC in the new world is leading a normal life just like how a normal human would lead a normal life in the real world.\n
3. The viewer's viewpoint. We know that Momonga is in fact a character from a game, somehow transported into this new world, but there is actually a real person in the real world who created this character.\n\n
How these 3 viewpoints were isolated so lucidly is precisely because of the fact that there are no other 'players' in the picture. At the same time, Momonga, while being a player, is the furthest thing from a human being as an all-powerful undead lich. I must say that it is brilliantly conjectured and brilliantly done.

I wanted to begin without breaking the whole spoiler. First of all. Its a MADHOUSE Studios, legendary studios which develop anime such as Death Note, One Punch Man, Iron Man the Animation, Parasyte, and so on. But this anime, you can say its a downfall and its finest.

“Overlord? Overrated more like!” – A goblin Jester from Overlord (a 2007 video game).
Overlord, is an anime about an extremely, ridiculously, tremendously overpowered so called “Overlord” who is actually…just a MMO player who found himself unable to log out from the game. Along with his uninteresting subordinates, he then goes on a rather boring journey to find his friends that are perhaps like him, trapped in the game world. That’s the story in a nutshell. Not entirely fresh in terms of premise, the only thing that’s new is the protagonist is a generic guy who is stuck in lich form.
In terms of action, its doesa fair job – however almost fails at it. Since not only Momonga(protagonist), but even his subordinates are outrageously powerful, any adversary are like flies to them, making the fights scenes less enjoyable to watch since the enemies can’t even put a dent on them – of course other than the last battle, where Momonga faced someone who is more or less powerful than him. Still, majority of the fights are very one sided.


Many of the characters frequently utter names of random “spells” or “buffs” – any average gamer definitely know what those terms means. Few “skills” sounded self-explanatory to avid gamers, but there were some called “See-through” and “Greater Hardening”, I don’t know what the hell they do, but it sure made me chuckle. The battles are most likely the only biggest redeeming factor in this show. Even so, the action is nothing jaw-dropping or cool and very far from awesome. It doesn't even reach “good”, in my standards. 


The characters are probably the weakest aspect - I wasn't particularly interested in any of them. Admittedly, Albedo was hot and she’s nice fap material, but other than that, I didn't find her particularly interesting, or unique whatsoever. Most of the time, she was just there to constantly praise Momonga – in fact, majority  of Momonga’s servants didn't do much as well. In the first episode, we are already introduced to most of the supporting cast: a giant insect man and a weird guy in a suit, whom both resembles generic villains, two possibly trap siblings and lastly, a vampire loli with fake boobs; that’s what I've been told. I can’t even remember their names too well either, other than having to Google it or probably rewatching an episode, which I’m probably not going to do.


Other aspects such as animation & art was alright, but it’s nothing memorable and the overall Sound was good.


In conclusion, Overlord is just a passable anime due to its rather mundane fights, combined with a cast of bland characters, while it does have a couple good moments in between, but still not entirely worthwhile. Do I recommend it? Well, I'd say, give it a shot - but don't expect too much.

To get rid of the obvious (and least important, IMO) first, animation is a disaster. Moving on.
I dived into Overlord on a recommendation from my best friend and a dedicated anime lover who usually has a pretty good idea of quality. Going by what they said, Overlord on a first note seemed like a very wholesome idea of a guy trying to help the remaining players trapped in the now real game-world, sprinkled with the sweet bits of edginess that is our titular character. I guess I thought it was going to be a bit like Goblin Slayer, if perhaps a bit less traumatic, andencompassing a bit more of cliche anime tropes and lighthearted bits of comedy/drama. And if it was anything close to that, Overlord would indeed be quite a solid watch.


Alas, Overlord suffers from an age old formula that turns MCs into gods, and everyone around them into tools who serve no other purpose than to further reiterate just how gosh-darn AMAZING their master is. This too, seemed at the beginning like it could be wholesome, because the scene itself is pretty sweet and  radiating a "gang getting together" vibe but sadly boiled down to nothing more than servitude. 


The little hope I had for a possible romantic sub-plot, the hint of which is in the very beginning of the first episode, was immediately wiped out by the fact there no love truly involved, as much as there is shameless fanservice and lewdness which, on some other genre and some other time, might be fantastic. In this very "edgy" series, it comes of as ridiculous. 


At some point, a dakimakura appears and kills all my good intentions towards world building.


It's just sad, because certain scenes in Overlord are pretty amazing. Certain bits a of otherwise terrible dialogue are pretty strong, characters are sometimes interesting. The problem is that it all comes down to that "sometimes" - Overlord is only good at very specific times, when something very specifically interesting or heavy is happening, which, on average, is three to five minutes per episode. It is simply not strong enough to carry on my interest, so the reason for why this series keeps on going remains a mystery to me.


Oh no, wait, of course, it's fantasy fulfillment. 


Figures. Because in that regard, Overlord is a fucking masterpiece.

The production value of this show is fine, It all looks and sounds very good. But the story is absolute garbage and I can't stop watching it.
The main character is a a player trapped inside a game where he is now a super powerful Lich. Women fight over not who will become his wife but rather who will become his first wife because he is so great that of course he will have a harem.
There's no challenge here for the cast. The main character has a small army under his control and most of them have the power to outclass a god of the worldthey're in. There is no threat that is introduced that even comes close to the main casts power level. 


There is no character development. The main character's entourage unconditionally loves him. They all think he's the greatest ever and bend over backwards to justify any stupid thing he might do. From start to finish they're all exactly as they were. As for the main character he's got some magic spell on him that they don't want to elaborate on that stunts his emotions so they've added an in universe reason why he can't develop as a character. 


There are no consequences. Right from the start the main character has the ability to resurrect anyone. So even if he were to lose everyone close to him he can just bring them back, and presumably the same can be done to him, but only his team has this power. 


But here's the thing, It's such a train wreck that I can't look away, There's always something happening, It'll have terrible pacing and be incredibly contrived but this is what I imagine the Japanese version of Axe Cop would be except it's made by adults and not a 4 year old.

Alright well since season 3 finished recently I decided to go back and review season 1 where it all began. 
This show is enjoyable to a great extent, it isn't flawless but it's still fantastic. The most common complaint i've heard is "The main character is OP" well no shit, they know what they are doing with him, if you are watching Overlord to see tense battles with high stakes then leave, let me give you a hint: AINS WINS. People complain about him being too strong well he is supposed to be, they never play at it like he is going to lose andyou aren't supposed to be worried about him. The entertainment value is in the interactions he has with other characters as well as the massive amount of side characters to get to know. My personal favorite is Shalltear and always will be due to how badass she is. My only gripes with it are that 1. The CG is super bad but it's funny to laugh at, and 2. The whole undercover adventurer thing doesn't come into use until season 3, which is really late but at least it plays a really important part in the story. It's story is really interesting due to how objective Ains feels about the world and people, he has no human emotion and therefore does stuff the way a evil undead king would, which is so refreshing instead of the stupid "SAVE EVERYONE BECAUSE LIFE IS PRECIOUS" approach. Save the village? Oh they are useful to my plans? Okay I guess I will then, but they will basically be my pawns to use when I need them. That is amazing, finally a main character that is fresh and interesting, he acts like someone trying to be a villain in an RPG and it's just perfect. So yeah this show is great, really loved it. Definitely worth a watch.

A simple review of this would be to watch a couple of episodes to see if you like it. You could really enjoy it or be burned out by the 3rd episode, just try it and see what happens. 
(Extended review) This is honestly my number one favorite Anime of all time. What makes this anime so great isn't the complexity of the story, on the contrary the fact that it's so simple makes me love this Anime. Overlord takes an old idea and makes it a masterpiece in it's own right. The story makes the title makes sense, Aniz Ooal Gown is as actualOverlord and during his fights the only reason why he doesn't destroy his enemy in one shot is to gain knowledge of the new world he's in. He's fighting to build up knowledge instead of power or money, he's also trying to gain a reputation so he can try to contact other people that may be trapped in the world with him, which I found to be interesting. Depending on how you like your main characters this can make or break you, if you like overpowered main characters that AREN'T 14 years old than this may be for you. However, if you want to see a long drawn out story where someone gets stronger through hard and rigorous training TURN AROUND and watch Kenichi Mightiest Disciple or something.


this could be 9/10 or 3/10 but still my favorite anime.

EXTREMELY MILD SPOILER REVIEW
So to start this off, I’ve heard multiple rumours saying that Overlord is not very good and is a ripoff of SAO. I have made my stance that it certainly isn’t.
Story 7/10
Well the plot was pretty generic but still a decent one. It involves much violence and hilarious overpowerness and of course Fantasy and magic much as described. The anime revolves around a guy that plays a VR game called Yggdrasil and got trapped in the game. He got trapped in the game for an unknown reason and unlike SAO, he was trapped alone.The NPCs in the game that should have been programmed by the system before he was trapped turned to life and started communicating him.


Funny thing is, we do not know who else is trapped but the NPCs still retain the settings they had before the player was trapped. Some parts can be extremely hilarious due to this.


The player that was trapped, Momonga-san decided to venture and search for potential players that are also trapped despite being trapped in a game that turned to life, he was surprisingly calm which bugs me abit when I first watched the anime but I’m all past that and now I anticipate what will happen next for every episode I watch. 


There is some violence in the anime but I enjoy it very much. The way Momonga is described at the beginning makes me feel that he is invincible not to mention his NPC servants that are almost equally powerful.


I anticipate if anyone can stand a chance against him and if any others exist with him.


The suspense is killing me and I highly recommend.
