What does the world look like when you're an evil overlord? What is the process of becoming a demon  king? If you've always pondered these questions watch Death Note or Code Geass, not Overlord. Or if you'd rather indulge in the cheap fantasy of wielding unmatched power, dominating kingdoms and commanding the devotion of hot babez...watch Overlord, but keep it to yourself. Sorry, that was unfair, someone could watch this show for legitimate reasons and perhaps be mildly entertained, but only mildly.
Character motivation is the big weakness. The protagonist's minions (most of the first and second tier cast) are principally moved by a lockstepdevotion to their Overlord, which might be inspiring if it were shown to be justified...but it's simply the result of their programming. Even their gratitude for real kindness the overlord show them is rendered forced and hollow. Or it might be interesting if such unthinking devotion were critiqued and analysed...but don't hold your breath for that. Unjustified, unanalysed devotion is simply bad character writing and pandering to audience fantasies, to say nothing of the female lead's unsavoury sexual devotion. Aside from motivation, the minions' differing characters are actually expressed quite well, but the turd in the waterpipe remains. The non-minion supporting characters might have some interest to them, aside from futile opposition to the protagonist, but, again, I'm not holding out much hope there.


The protagonist spends more time flaunting his excessive power than displaying interesting character traits, or any reason for us to support or sympathise with him (possibly such a reason will come later, but it really should be there from the start) He disposes of the world he was born in with a line or two 'I have no ties or family', making the MMORG premise, (aside from conveying a sense of isolation that his minion's devotion promptly quenches) worse used than in any similar series. His base motivation of conquering the world in order to meet other stranded role-players is worse than his minions; the plot that is produced by such motivations appeared almost entirely, if not completely, uninteresting. And of course this is a light novel adaption, so nothing significant about this pile of tedium is likely to be changed in thirteen episodes. I may only have got through three of them, but the impression I received, of ongoing trends as well, was just that bad.

REVIEW CONTAINS SPOILERS.
This anime is a very clever take on a hypothetical situation: What would happen if you were suddenly transported into the body of your character in an MMO? You're suddenly this super powerful skeletal wizard and you have control over a kingdom. What do you even do?
The resultant storyline of the main character Momonga (Ainz Ooal Gown, or AOG for the rest of this review) seeking to make himself famous in this weird new world is absolutely well done. Below are some notes I took during my viewing of the show.
POSITIVES:
> Manages to make the viewer care about every single character that comeson screen. Almost none of the characters we see are one-dimensional in any way (despite some visual problems I'll get to later).\n
> Story is realistic, with AOG doing what any ordinary person might do given such an unexpected situation.\n
> The themes of past glory and friendship echo throughout the season, with AOG mourning the disappearance of his old guildmates in episode 1, and again throughout the story. Teamwork and mateship is something that isn't treated lightly in this series.\n
> The societies and communities that exist in the world are all quite realistic, but with unique spins on them that clearly echo MMO game mechanics. For example, in the town of E-Rantel there is a building where adventurers can go to receive quests, and are rewarded with money and standing within the local guild as a result. However none of this is treated as a gimmick, and functions very realistically.\n
> The voice acting in the show is generally good (with some notable exceptions that will be touched on later). A particularly well-done performance is that of Clementine. Her psychosis and disregard for others is conveyed incredibly well. Pandora's Actor is also very well voiced; yes, the character is intentionally lame and cringey, and yes, it's played to perfection, making the startled and furious reaction of AOG believable (as the entire audience is having the same reaction).\n
> Normally, 3D cel animation is really badly done in anime, but Overlord benefits from it, despite it occasionally being jarring (the battle between Narberal and Khajit being a particularly strange example).\n
> The opening theme, Clattanoia, is phenomenally good, and ranks as one of my favourite anime openings.\n
> The balance between comedy and drama is good, managing the audience's emotions in such a way as to ensure they never get too bogged down in negative emotions, or too comfortable with positive ones. By contrast. Hellsing is an anime that suffers because it doesn't have much in the way of levity, and thus bogs down the viewer. When I watched Hellsing Ultimate I couldn't watch it for more than a few episodes, as it was so tedious in its gratuity.\n
> Some of the themes presented are surprisingly progressive. It's revealed that a supposedly male member of the adventurer's party AOG travels with midway through the series is female, and the reason for her secrecy is because of the group's prejudice against female adventurers. \n\n
NEGATIVES:\n\n
> Some of the characters in Overlord are clearly representations of classic archetypes. The Wise King of the Forest is clearly just there for comic relief and to embarrass AOG, while Albedo's presence as a character seems little more than to be a (very sexual) love interest to AOG. Her conflict with Shalltear over both character's love for AOG borders on "yandere"  levels of insanity. Shalltear very closely follows the trope of "gothic lolita", as she dresses in the clothing, and happens to be a vampire. To her credit though, her brief "lamprey" transformation later on in the series throws this cliche out the window. Narberal is a straight up "tsundere", as well as a "battle maid". Adherence to these archetypes is detrimental to the quality of the show, because it removes opportunities for more nuanced exploration of the characters, and seems to just be for the sake of fanservice.\n
> While we're talking about fanservice, it's bad. Really bad. Whenever Albedo is on screen, she's either shamelessly professing her love for AOG, defending AOG from attacks, fighting with Shalltear over AOG, or just talking about AOG in general. The worst case of this is when the demon character Demiurge finds Albedo in her bedchamber, apparently masturbating with an AOG body pillow. I suppose the intended comic relief in all this is AOG is a skeleton, and so possesses no sex organs, but the joke falls flat every time, and is therefore very lame.\n
> It's very clear that the creators of Overlord are angling for a second season, because several of the character's we've seen have not been fleshed out at all. Gazef, Brain, everyone in the Slane Theocracy, Cocytus, Demiurge, and the twin dark elves come to mind immediately. However, just because an anime is angling for a second season doesn't mean these characters can be so conspicuously flat; it's a cheap tactic and mars the quality of what is otherwise a very good show.

This is my question: Is the anime better without reading the novel? Because i read the novel and this causes me a discomfort when I see it's animated adaptation.
This anime summarizes the first three novels in only twelve episodes, and this causes that, for those who have read the original work, leave some obvious plot holes.
The first time I saw this anime, I thought the shounen I had was great; but after reading the novels later, I see that this adaptation is very bad, speaking hypocritically. I liked the voice of some characters, but it is not enough to solve the problem with the rolesof each character; because, honestly, there are many characters that did not even last a minute.


The reason why I saw this anime was because someone told me that "It is an inverse shounen, where the protagonist, instead of venturing into nothingness in search of more power, he already has the power", and although this has similarities With SAO, at least I found it interesting to see something different.


I liked the design of the characters, which I think go according to the original, but there were errors and bad designs in the animation in many parts of the anime (like the CGI, for example); and as I said above, the lack of protagonism in the characters.


If someone really recommends this work, or would like to see it, better read the novel because before risking this adaptation, even if it is something similar to SAO. It is my personal opinion.

So I finally got around to watching this and I started understanding why people like it so much.
I like the isekai genre through all its faults. However, this over-saturation makes it hard for shows to stand out often. Of course we get our SAO's which are big by being mainstream, but we also get Konosuba style shows that have enough meta-comentary on RPG's or games with a cast of lovable characters to be fun and entertaining.
Overlord seems to break plenty of these bonds by achieving most of them very well. Now, it is somewhat mainstream, it has bouts of comedy, and I find myself caringfor each character on Ains' team. The biggest success however is playing it straight with no true story to be seen. You really see that the only goals in this world aren't a major story quest, but the goal that Ains' and other decide to set for themselves. Sure, he sets out to find out if any other players exist in the world, however, we also see that he has become more identified with his lich form. He cares for these characters not for their race, but for the bonds he build with his guild-mates over those previous 7 years.


While you have Ains' playing the stereotypical OP MC role that you see in a lot of isekai, they break the mold slightly by showing most of his though processes throughout his ordeal. Ains' doesnt' seem to have any idle plans, and he is trying to think of an actual outcome to any battle he's in. He knows the value of knowledge, and that's the asset he plays the most. He never goes into a battle with a disadvantage because he already made sure to protect and buff the disadvantages he might have. He truly embodies the idea of "never start a fight you know you can't win". I was even refreshed to see him retreat when needed rather than bash his skull (got a pun in) against a fictional wall to prove his bravery.


It's interesting to watch this world develop as it's both familiar and unfamiliar to Ains. He has to reconcile what he knows from his experience, and what he must find out. Even being powerful, it doesn't ever imply he's invincible. Heavy costs come with poor decisions, and you can often feel the weight of each decision he makes for the good of the guild.


The show felt like it had some smarts to it, and more importantly, it impressed this upon the viewer when he came out on top. Sure, magic gives you some leeway; but, often they at least would show you the train of thought they had to make Ains come out on top in an encounter. One thing is for sure, when I start Overlord II I know everyone is going to want off "Mr. Bones' Wild Ride"

Story (5/10)
-Overlord is way too heavy of a title for an anime of this mediocrity. The storyline is linear, but the pacing is almost atrocious. This anime is based off of a Light Novel, which would explain the weirdly-timed comedy and snail-speed pacing disguised as slow burn plot progression. I'm almost completely convinced that to make an RPG anime that would actually show what an RPG is like would take several seasons, and then some more for plot progression.
-The story does not feel entirely fleshed out, and the entire season felt like it could have finished in 3 episodes if paced right. The "final bossfight" would have been epic if I actually knew the characters behind the weapons used, but instead I'm left out of the loop with three Guardians trying to narrate a boring fight in my ear.


Art (7/10)

-Madhouse was supposedly famous for its fight scenes, and I barely got to see any fight scenes actually worth noting in this show. Anatomy-wise, Madhouse exceeds expectations as usual. Animation-wise, it was completely lacking with respect to the studio.

-Heavy scenes were superimposed with cringe-worthy CGI that Madhouse tried to get away with through a mix of 2D and 3D character animation during these sequences, and that was just about the only real effort I saw in terms of art. The colors bounced off computer-generated skins that alluded to its RPG-world graphics, but I can't let that excuse the laziness this anime was left with.

-The art wasn't bad, per say, but it had a lot lacking. I'm just glad there were no inconsistencies.


Sound (5/10)

Opening Song

-I watched the first episode's OP, got tired of it, and skipped it every chance I got after. Just so you know, the intros range from 1:10-4:00, and the estimated time of the entire OP is 1:20. I memorized that just so I could accurately skip it.

-On that note, it's probably because I really don't care for pop rock songs. Especially ones that mix English with Japanese.

Ending Song

-Similarly treated like the OP, except I watched the second episode's ED as well just because I wanted to hear the singer say "fxxking" again.

-Still rock. Still don't like it.

Soundtrack

-Was there one? I would expect there to be at least mildly epic fight music but it was left as classical choir singing notes just as the climax hits. Not bad, but nothing new here.

-Lack of mood-setting music. There's no real game music whatsoever, and the range of song diversity falls flat.


Characters (3/10)

-This is what I wanted to get into: there are hardly any real characters. We just mostly see Momonga's unmoving skeletal face and hear an inner voice for endless monologues. I never felt a connection or any empathy towards him missing his fellow guild members. I don't even remember them much, besides that they had ridiculous names. Even the Nazarick NPCs were left for me to just wonder about, even if they were such a small cast. I still don't know how many maids there are or any of their names besides Nabe, and I only remember her because we were stuck with her for, like, 4 episodes.

-We never even get to see what Momonga was like in real-life. Peeved me.


Enjoyment (6/10)

-I thought I would enjoy this a lot more. To be honest, with the title Overlord, I thought there would be a lot more of him lording over things and people.

-Some jokes were funny, even some dirty scenes here and there, and I can't say I didn't enjoy them but I can't say they'll make me laugh every time either.

Story: 7/10
Basically, a virtual reality game (think SAO, but actually good)  is going offline forever. Man decides to stay until the end. He and the NPCS in his guild are transported into another fantasy world and everyone becomes real, and so does the magic he used in the old game. 
The story isn't the best I've seen, but it was still good and there were certain aspects of the story I really liked. I thought the concept of the series was brilliant, which gets some plus points, but it could've been executed slightly better towards the middle.  I didn't really like the factthat Ainz joined a guild in the new world they found themselves in, but that choice did lead to a few good scenes (all the ones with Clementine in them).


Even with the flaws, the story was made well enough that it deserves to be watched. I enjoyed it.


 I really hope that Overlord gets a sequel. 


Art: 9/10


The animation was quite good. The art style was likable, the art itself was well rendered, and the actual animation was fluid and clean. 



Sound: 8/10


The opening and ending were deliciously good. I don't remember a thing about the rest of the soundtrack - unmemorable but not awful I guess - but good god the opening and ending were amazing. It was one of those series where I watch the opening and the ending in their entirety every episode.


The voice acting was quite good as well (Clementine and Ainz had terrific voice acting.) Sound effects would well done too. 



Characters: 7/10


I think Overlord had a pretty good cast. Ainz, Albedo, and Clementine were the shining stars of the cast. The rest were not bad by any means, but it kind of disappointed me that more of Ainz's servants weren't expanded upon more (a lot of the series they weren't there because he was in the E-Rantel guild.)



Enjoyment: 8/10



Overall: 7.8. I'll round it up and give it an 8/10 for the official score. Not bad at all.

After watching the final episode of Overlord, and taking some time to compile my thoughts on it, I hopefully have put together a coherent series of words to describe my thoughts.
In case you don't already know, Overlord is about our oh-so-normal gaming fanatic who poured his life into the virtual reality game Yggdrasil, however, due to whatever reasons, after 12 years of service, is shutting down. The MC, Momonga, decided to stay with his guild headquarters, The Great Tomb of Nazarick, which his guild, composed of 41 members painstakingly created. Thought, over the years of the game, eventually all but 4 of the members quitbecause their real lives took precedence. Lonely, Momonga takes up the guild weapon, the Staff of Ainz Ooal Gown, which was a huge guild undertaking to make, to the throne room. He sits on the throne, and waits to be kicked from the game when the server shuts down at midnight. Midnight rolls past, and he is still in the game. The non-player characters whom always had just the basic level of AI, spoke to him. After confirming, they were now flesh-and-blood living people. However, he isn't just a human character, actually... none of the characters in Nazarick are. Momonga, realizing his life in reality isn't really worth much, so he decides to stay... and conquer this world!


Now to the review-ish bits.


Animation: Madhouse be praised, the quality of the animation is fantastic. Each of the characters is well drawn, colored, and animated. The CG that was done was well integrated and not intrusive or ugly. When it comes to animation, Madhouse doesn't disappoint. 5/5


Sound/Music: The sound and music of Overlord is pretty damn good, the OP/ED are catchy, the ambient music and sound effects are synced, and nothing sounds out of place or weird. 5/5


Characters: Madhouse did very well with the first few episodes, giving the important time with the NPC's interacting with one another, easily getting across who they are and what they think of each other, and Momonga. I truly like the dynamic of the characters with Momonga, when he speaks, they shut up and give him undivided attention. Even the love-stricken Albedo obeys instantly, even if she doesn't like it. With a LN adaptation such as this, characters can't really get the development that you hope, but they can only pour so much into thirteen episodes. So on characters, 4/5


Story: As far as the story goes, a lot of worry was emphasized on being an 'SAO clone,' and I was kind of worried it would turn off a lot of people from the show. However, episode 3 rolled around and it took that assumption and threw it out a window. The story was well paced, up till i want to say the last 3 episodes. They skipped almost all of The Bloody Valkyrie, but I can forgive them because they did an excellent job in keeping the story tidy and smooth for anime-only watchers. But as a LN reader, I was pretty disappointed. If i look at it from a Anime only standpoint, 4/5


Overall: In my opinion, Overlord was excellent. Madhouse turned one of my favorite light novels into a damn good adaptation. The fights were epic, the dialogue was well written, and it felt like the book I had read. I have to say, this was my favorite of the season. I sincerely hope for season 2, as long as Madhouse does it. I feel like it stands on it's own and breaks a new path in the 'trapped in a game' genre. It is also truly worth reading the novels, as they are some of the best out there at the moment.

I didn’t think I’d masturbate to an undead - Overlord review
From my first perception of Overlord, what caught my eyes were the punk-ish stylish look of the cover art. What turned me off was my assumption, from the description, that it was going to be another shitty fucking SAO. But then I read a comment saying to not put them on the same plane. I am pleased.
The virtual mmorpg Yggdrasil is on its last active day before shutting down completely. Momonga is the guild master of the guild Ainz Ooal Gown. Everyone of the guild members, his closest friends, have left to continue with theirjobs and feed their family. He is the sole remaining member. When he decides to stay in the game until getting kicked out by the server shutdown, he has strangely not been logged out. He cannot log out nor contact the GMs. He quickly finds out that the game is not a game anymore but a strange reality. The NPCs, his senses etc. have all become real in the strange phenomenon. Now he seeks to learn more about his fate in order to live in this world.


I delved into Overlord with a neutral expectation. I adore the idea of an mmorpg anime, however, it does a great job of making you forget that it is actually an mmorpg while still being one. It does a great job of making you forget that the main character is human. And I’ll explain why. The world setting is of that mmorpg aspects are a part of the normal, seemingly integrated in a masterfully blended way. NPCs will have no questions towards cash shop items or the usual game terms because it’s a part of the world, at least to those of Nazarick for the most part. Momonga is a human being, and since he’s a real undead in an assumingly real world, he has done things he normally would’ve regretted or felt undeniably guilty because of his passive skill as an undead to not feel emotions. As the show progresses, he kills and hurts humans, whether they are evil or not, for the sake of his plan. It manipulates the audience smoothly with ease, progressively diverting our thoughts of reminder that it’s an mmorpg based show.


Madhouse does it again giving Overlord the writing and direction needed for a damn good show. The connecting ideas within the story build this bridge in a universe that we come to care about, and not just some deus ex machina or random event without any idea or purpose behind it. It sets up future scenarios from various moments in previous episodes or events prior to that scene. While regrettably Overlord is only a 13 episode show, it delivers satisfyingly and tells quite a compelling contained story during that span of episodes. It sets up a season 2 perfectly, and by no means is it a sequel bait. The final conflict ends where it concludes nicely, then goes on to bring up sequences of events to hype us even more for what’s to expect. Madhouse being Madhouse serves up quality art and animation. They’ve created a foreboding atmosphere and a gritty setting. Though the CGI in anime like always seem out of place, but for Overlord you’ll forgive it as it delivers in action and a satisfying range in narrative. Onto sound, it’s great. Each voice actor does their part fitting of the characters they’re portraying. For example, Momonga when he monologues in his human voice then transitioning to his character’s voice makes it a great dynamic. Or Clementine when she screams in agony is so weirdly pleasuring. I think it did its job. The bgms assist the impactful scenes furthering the curiosity of upcoming scenes. Opening and ending are perfect. The intro and ending sequences along with the songs are a perfect date for one another. It’s crisp clean. 


The characters for the most part are reserved and collected, Momonga especially, acting the part, for the sake of being of Nazarick’s citizens last and remaining supreme ruler. While not everyone gets the screen time to develop, from the start everyone is already at a mutual and respectable character. Momonga is our main protagonist, he uses his knowledge from what has learned in Yggdrasil when it was an mmorpg to communicate in the world he currently resides in. He shows he is not naive and reckless by taking reserved actions and scouting the world, even for someone as supreme as him, a max leveled player with godly gears and items. While he may seem consumed into being “anti-human” via the undead passive he has, Momonga still has his human side. We see that he’s still perplexed as to what to do in this world and misses his friends who have all left Nazarick. At first Albedo’s absolute love and devotion to Momonga turned me off, even though he changed her settings right before the game became reality, she easily won me over for not overreacting in the most annoying way. In fact, she is quite hilarious. For example when Momonga gave her a guild member ring and left, she quickly turned around and just made a funny reaction. But the best example of her character is how she portrays her devotion to Momonga during their fight against the Slaine Theocracy within the first few episodes. It may seem cliche of her character but it works well. She was quite bad ass for the short lived moment it was. The rest of the cast like I said is mutually respectable. They don’t have essential roles in the story as of yet, but for what they’ve done to support Momonga is commendable and I was actually fine. I didn’t find them at all a nuisance nor hindrance, but of worthy extension in the cast. My personal favorite being Cocytus, a collective and charming insectoid warrior ‘thingy’. Everyone else is pretty derivative of some character trait, however which is reasoned by how much of an otaku the 41 supreme beings were. They created them to represent themselves, or their favorite type of characters. Which in real life, if anyone had the chance, we wouldn’t actually think of creating a super in depth character with a sophisticated and grim backstory. No. We would just make them simple and have fun. But any how, none of the characters I found were at any point a bother.


I was wrong to to think of Overlord to be a rip off only to capitalize on the recent mmorpg boom. It stands on its own, much stronger than SAO, Dot Hack, and Log Horizon. It’s unique to itself as a series. And that it why Overlord earns a 9/10 with an Undead body pillow seal of approval. It has a great narrative written exceptionally and adequately stands out the most of those in its genre. It shows and tells us why it deserves a sequel, and it earns it. An awesome story like this cannot be left hanging on a thread. Capitalize all you want Madhouse, you’ve done it again. I’ll see you guys on my next review.

Overlord is an adaptation from the light novel by Kugane Maruyama and illustrated by so-bin. I have personally watched all 13 animated episodes and overall, everything was perfect. Everything from the animation and voice acting was very well polished, even though they cut some minor parts from the light novel, but this is due to time constraints. Hence, it was expected and acceptable. To my knowledge, they're only planning to animate only for volume 1 of the light novel. Personally, I can see this anime go a long way. I can already see the overwhelming popularity this anime has gotten since the animated release. Ihope Madhouse plan on making another season or more cause this anime deserves it.

I've dropped A LOT of animes using the MMORPG universe. I'm not fond of them and I feel they are very telegraphed. There's usually little element of surprise in the story or the characters. The people who created Hack// must feel really bad for giving birth to this animation sub-genre. 
At first I wasn't at all interested in Overlord but a friend of mine recommended it so I gave it a try. I was kinda hooked from episode 1 because of the whole "the MC is an evil liche king stuck in a video game" and not "a fighter grouping with other adventurers to setthemselves free from the MMO curse".


Story: 5/10

The server of a famous MMORPG is closing and a player gets stuck inside. He's the leader of a famous guild but all his friends stopped playing a long time ago. He realises he's stuck there with the harem of NPCs they programmed who become human-like after the servers close. By human-like I mean they have feeling etc. The MC's avatar is a pretty badass Liche King called Momonsan. Once the servers are closed his own feelings get erased and he thinks like a Liche King while still remembering he's human IRL.

So pretty basic setup overall, he then realizes there's a human world he can access and tries to find other players. He joins an adventurer guild to learn more about the human world and disguises himself as a huge knight in armor.

While the story is not very original its still kind of catchy until episode 8-9. Then it just goes down a hole which really disappointed me. The last 4 episodes were utter rubish.


Art: 6/10

While it's not amazing it's pretty consistent. Nothing crazy with the art style, the action is well animated but don't expect to have your brainz blown out.


Sound: 6/10

The dubbing is good but both the opening and ending kinda sucked. Thumbs up for the sound effects though.


Character: 7/10

Momonsan (the MC) is cool but his harem of NPCs who wanna ride his dick are a lot less adorable. Maybe I don't get the whole lolli thing. Still giving a 7 for the heartbreaking story with the adventurer group.


Enjoyment : 5/10

The last episodes just ruined it for me. No fun whatsoever watching them. The final fight is fine but the opponent is terrible. A lot of disappointement there. If you miss SOA and that kind of gibberish then you'll probably like this a lot more than me. Everything just falls apart at the end and the plot is full of hole. These inconsistencies make it hard for me to give it a higher grade than 5.


In conclusion not a bad anime but a very disappointing one. It get's your hopes up but nothing happens in the end. A very bland first season.


Overal : 5/10

Basically there's a guy who's really a giant skeleton, that goes around trowing over powered magic spells around and being a major badass. 
It's fun to watch, mostly because he's actually quite the normal guy, a normal online player that finds himself becoming his online avatar while his friendly NPCS come to life. 
Unlike SAO this guy doesn't have to become stronger, he's already overpowered enough and he knows it. 
The Guardians are all pretty different from each other, which brings on different flavours into it. Not to mention the battle maids, which are pretty badasses themselves. 
In therm os antagonists, well, the blonde crazyone annoyed the hell out of me but I had fun watching her die, so no biggie. \n\n
Plus, the comic relief is quite good. Overall, something funny to watch on a Saturday.

Overlord is an anime adaptation of the Light Novel by Maruyama Kugame and So-Bin, and covers up to volume 3. It is loosely-based upon Dungeons and Dragons rules and character creation.
Although it begins with an MMO it is not a "trapped in an MMO anime" as the main player character Momonga, his guild base and NPCs are all transferred to a fantasy world with all the typical knights, magic casters, adventuring guilds and monsters. Overlord is very character driven and it is entertaining to watch their interactions with each other as well as the New World inhabitants. The MC Momonga/Ainz is who we seethe most of, the story follows his newfound abilities as well as his loneliness in the new world, as he searches this world for his past guildmates.\n\n
See how an ordinary japanese salaryman who spent all his time and money on a MMO becomes a skeleton magical caster in a fantasy world. Follow him as he explores this world and its people,  ensuring the protection of the guild his friends made while also attempting to convince his suddenly sentient(and sometimes evil) guild NPCs that hes an all powerful Overlord.

Overlord is what SAO should have been; there is no other way to describe it. 
Overlord begins by throwing you straight into the action and dynamics of the game, with the main focus being on Ainz Ooal Gown - a coterie (or intimately close guild) that plans to take over the land of Yggdrasii. While some may argue that this can be daunting or rather, offputting at first, the immersive story and brilliant dialogue keep you wanting to digest more information about this intricate online game. Its plot can be rocky at times and, not to mention, there are some episodes that seem too rushed.However, the depth of these episodes and how far they delve in exploring the relationships between the numerous characters feels enriching. 


And that leads me to my next point. 


The characters are a work of art themselves. They are each, for the most part, imbued with different and complex personalities: lord Ains comes across as cold, callous, and calculating at first - however when his outer mental wall is stripped away, we get to see his finitely caring and selfless temperament. And sometimes, the characters need not possess depth; instead, their deep love and intense admiration (to the point of idolization) for Lord Ains is funny and strangely gripping on its own. The only problem is that there is just not enough of them.


There is a wealth of lore and history within the land of Yggdrasil - even a blind man could see that. And that, on its own, serves as effective temptation to draw you in. But one thing the anime lacks is the motive and time to dig up this knowledge and explore the different magic types and combat skills (online gaming paraphernalia) in enough detail that would be satisfying. This kind of 'skimming over' is my main problem with the anime. 


It is also obligatory to mention that the combat is on another level. From the range of magic attacks cast by Lord Mormonga, or the physical parries by Shaltear, almost every action scene leaves you on the edge of your seat - wanting, desiring, and craving more. 


All in all, if you were left feeling unsatisfied with the undelivered potential and promise of SAO, Overlord will make up for the faults of its inferior predecessor and add more depth and lore, in measure of plot, combat, character, and plot.

The story is great, full of adventures and characters well done. The art is wonderful, good and with a style of its own that is not like any other anime of the genre. The characters are the best are very well done. Wonderful anime, the best anime I've ever seen. The story is incredible.
The animations are of a wonderful quality, the soundtrack is flawless. The art of animation is really good. The best I've ever seen.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
My congratulations to all involved in the production, audio, animation and voice. They did an EXCELLENT job.
OVERLORD is the best anime I've ever seen.

Its safe to say that Overlord does not fit in the standard form of simply rating anime. Overlord is to be glorified and adored for many reasons. After the critically acclaimed Sword art online the craze started, the world wanted more anime like it, they wanted more Isekai. Many came following Sword art online's popularity, shows like Log Horizon and many others began to surface out of the depths of great Manga and amidst all the isekai to emerge, came Overlord. Overlord follows the same base idea of many isekai anime, that being a person is somehow transported into a fantasy or game like worldwith some iterations giving the main character some kind of overpowered boost that sets him from the rest of the world. Overlord is no exception to this. Although this is the case, Overlord seemingly and effortlessly makes an already overused idea into something enjoyable to watch. clever writing and direction really set the tone for the entire anime. There are moments where the audience already knows the might of the main character and that he/she has the capabilities of destroying worlds but time and time again the audience is lured into a false sense of power. The unknown is truly what scares most and the main character is fully aware and wants to be absolutely sure when continuing on with his plans.\n\n
It's destructive, and it's powerful. Overlord delivers everything that an isekai fan yearns for and a pleasant watch for newcomers to the series or anime in general. The music and soundtracks ooze power and pump adrenaline into the audience, the characters are well fleshed out and each character is far from a stale personality, they all have that bump. The anime is enjoyable to the very end and keeps the fans wanting more and more. Luckily by the time of me writing this review, the second season for Overlord is airing and is just as exciting if not more than its predecessor.

(SPOILERS for the first episode.)
A likable protagonist? In my isekai anime? It's more likely than you think. 
In fact, our hero's likability is pretty much what saves Overlord from becoming a huge bore. As Momonga, Satoru Suzuki is extremely overpowered, as you might guess from the show's title. Time in and time out, he manages to use his gaming prowess to defeat his enemies. 
Thankfully, the show manages to be less like another No Game No Life and more like One-Punch Man in this regard; under the overpowered skeleton surface, Momonga is a genuinely relatable everyman. He's the kind of dork who communicates with hisfellow players using cartoonish smilies that contrast with his creepy avatar and spends the last day of his favorite MMO's existence screwing around with all the power he's amassed throughout his time playing. Seeing him so all the silly, sentimental things I could see myself doing if one of my favorite games was closing got me firmly on board with him as a character. 


That's not to say our hero, along with Madhouse's stellar-as-usual artwork and sound, can save the show from every single flaw though. One of Overlord's biggest issues is in its pacing. While earlier episodes go by at a pretty steady pace, the overall arc starts to slow down in later parts and eventually goes full on One Piece shonen battle pacing by the end. While you might be able to tell from One Piece being firmly placed in my favorite anime that this didn't really bother me, I can see how it can feel slow if you're not the kind of viewer who is used to it. 


As far as genres I'm not as big of a fan of there are also times the show teeters towards becoming a harem anime, with scenes where female characters argue over the usual harem crap. This was annoying and honestly felt kind of out of place with everything else, especially with Momonga himself being uncomfortable with it. 


Another shortcoming of the anime is standard for the isekai genre at this point: the world of Yggdrassil is just your very bland, standard MMO. There's not much to see that's unique here. 


Overall, while not perfect, Overlord pleasantly surprised me. It's one of the first Isekai anime I've watched where I honestly related to the protagonist, and I enjoyed the shonen elements. I look forward to catching season 2 of this show in the future.

So first things first, it must be established that anime is for the most part subjective, so this review will only cater to people that have similar taste in anime as me. Now, I don't care about all that nonsense about story/character writing, character development, etc. stuff that people like to judge an anime based on. I was pretty entertained by this anime, and how entertaining it was is basically the only thing that matters. If you liked One-Punch Man, you'll probably like this anime too. Nothing really much to say because reviews are bullshit anyway. I liked Overlord, and I would give it a9/10.

Seeing Overlord for the first time will make you think “oh…it’s just another op MC trapped in a game kind of thing” but that all change when I actually finished it. Although the “being stuck in a virtual game” genre became a cliché nowadays because of a certain anime if you know what I mean…and of top of that the OP main character with ridiculous amount of strength is obviously a cliché too. But this anime in particular is unique in its own way especially anime in this particular genre or setting. The difference is in its different views on certain subjects from the charactersideals and ambitions to total action packed OP badass that will make awe. 


The story revolves around a player trapped in a virtual game that turned reality and progresses into conquest of the land. Even though the plot is cliché the story is not. The small detail of how the anime captures the memories of your comrades the hardships and joys of in-game achievement and adventures and the pain and loneliness of seeing your friends dwindle one by one leaving you all by yourself while gazing at the room that was once filled with you and your teammate’s joys and laughter. On the bright side the story it is quite enjoyable it can be complicated at times when they are explaining certain gaming elements and stuff. The introduction is relatively slow to because of the introduction of the main characters and the supporting characters. However, as the story progresses the pacing and flow of the story changes from slow to moderate just like the rising and falling of events on the story. One of the most interesting factor on this anime is the MC or the subjects main point of views in the story that has a different feel or rather does not tie to the “shounen protagonist/hero cliché” that fights for justice and etc. It’s not only the views of the main character but also the stories the different approach on thinking logically, strategically, emotionally and acting by principle. The anime gives you the question “What should be the right approach on the current situation/circumstances?” and also the phrase “Everything has a reason/price in what you do”. The conclusion of this anime will make you want for more or a second season in particular. The ending is in fact a mild ending scene; it is not too bad or does not have a major plot twist or impact. It just wants to make you want for more.


The art style is actually good they did a good job with the use of some CG animation to feature some action sequences that are badass and impressive. The art fits with fantasy like setting and the mix of effects on scenes with fighting and usage of magic that smoothly mixes with the story. The representation of the characters personality matches with the art especially the MC’s “Overlord” physique and representation. The most promising factor is the production gives the audience the blood and violence that the audience yearned for in a simple yet badass representation of blood and gore. It is not too gory and not to plain “no blood” killings. Also not over censored blood and gore that cover the entire anime.

The voice actors portrayed the characters personality traits quite realistically. The BGM differs and is somewhat is in sync with the atmosphere of the story. The Opening and Ending song of the anime are in my opinion are awesome. The Opening for me represents the Overlord’s ambition, thoughts and emotions. The Ending song is amazing with its mixture of metal and distorted electronic that is simply awesome.

The characters development in the story is good the progression of each character but mainly the protagonist can be easily seen by the changes and circumstances of the events and situation and how they can cope with it. 

The characters portrayal and the development of each one with their different personalities and principles are quite interesting.


In conclusion the anime overlord achieved somewhat my expectation on the trapped in a video game setting by giving it a different approach and unique points of view than the usual “shounen protagonist troupe”. The overall enjoyment is amazing it will give you incites in the different aspects on what will you do or the choices that may affect your judgment. While it has a deeper feel of being the last member of your guild and the only one who’s trying to preserve it by making well known to the land. Truly one of my favorite anime, highly recommended for the people who likes a different views besides the usually cliché style of delivering while it still has that OP character that is badass and amusing at the same time.

Story 6/10
Another story about someone stuck in MMORPG without having any explanation for this and he seeks answers and to achieve this he tries to dominate the world of this game.
Art 7/10
The fights are very well animated and the design characters are well done, but some effects and moves of the characters without being in fights is a little below expected.
Sound 8/10
Excluding opening and ending OST is very common. But I'm giving this high note because I loved the overlord's opening.
Character 5/10
I feel that the character is not developing in this story, even because he is completely invincible, at least in this first season. Aseveryone is following their schedule there are no well-crafted dialogues.\n\n
Enjoyment 9/10\n
Despite being a theme that is always appearing in the anime, an excellent work, overlord got my attention after EP 3 with great fights and a good development of these stories. One thing that detracted from my appreciation of the work was the excess of ecchi in the early episodes.\n

Overlord takes the trapped in a video game concept and executes it better than SAO.
Story: 7
It's a fun story, it really makes you want to know why they're stuck there, why did it happen? It grabs you and doesn't let you go; great for bingeing. Although, there were a few things that broke me out of it. One or too inconsistencies and odd writing, but nothing too terrible, I think.
Art: 8
It's good, it fits well and I didn't see anything that bothered me.
Sound: 10

Character: 7\n

My first reaction as this anime began was oh god not another one, as I had recently watched Log Horizon, and Sword Art Online (both seasons for both). I had also just finished One Punch man and was looking for something to recapture the fun I had.
-Story 
Despite the story having been cut and shortened from what I could tell (missing plot points, and conversations left half-way) the story for the most part made sense. Despite the hidden aspects of the plot, the story doesn't feel forced, and has a nice flow to it. 
-Art
Each character looks unique and easy to differentiate. Despite certain artassets looking old (eg. bad cg skeletons in the first 2 mins of the first episode) none of them look bad. Even the old art assets fit the anime, and sometimes even add to the anime's charm.


-Sound

The sound effects always add to the impact of an action, and sometimes even manage to make you just listen instead of see. Each character sounds different although some fall to the super high pitch territory some may find annoying.


-Character

As mentioned, since each character looks and sounds different they are easy to identify. Most characters are only glossed over as the anime is quite short and goes into the plot before much self explanation happens. The characters hopes and dreams become clear from the actions they take, although some will take a while to figure out. Some side characters end up being a bit flat, but the world building makes you believe that you just missed the parts that gave them more depth. In the end the characters are fitting for the plot.


-Enjoyment

This anime felt like a perfect mix of One Punch Man, Log Horizon, and Sword Art Online. It managed to conjoin the humor from One Punch Man, with the political intrigue of Log Horizon, and tied it all together with the action of Sword Art Online. I had an absolute blast watching, and re-watching, and re-watching, and re-watching this anime, and I will probably re-watch it again in the future. 


-Overall

I gave this anime a 10 not because it was flawless, but because the flaws add to the experience. Overlord is an anime that if you like the premise, once you start won't stop. It is an anime that makes the 24 min episode seem like 12 min episodes at most, and when it is done you wish for more. This was at least my opinion.


My fingers are crossed for season 2

This was definitely the best ‘trapped in a game’ anime that I’ve seen so far. It wasn’t a masterpiece, but still well worth watching.
Animation – no complaints. The art style was attractive and done appropriately for the mood and setting.
The sound was decent, and the voice acting cast was great. The opening and ending themes are acquired tastes, so you’ll either love them or hate them. However they did actually complement the anime, contrasting well with the generally more apathetic MC and tone of the anime.
The premise has been done before, but this series had a unique twist to it – the MC was trappedin the game by himself! (At least for the duration of the anime, which in any case is what I’m reviewing.) This actually played out in a really interesting manner, we got to see the MC adapt to everything by himself, as the only human with nothing but NPCs to rely on (and these were generally NPCs that he and other players had themselves created). The story is about how the MC reacts to his new surroundings and faces the challenges that come with it – therefore, not too focussed on character interaction, which was refreshing. 


I did like most of the supporting characters. Even though they didn’t receive much development (due to the story being event and environment driven), their personalities meshed pleasantly with each other. There were a few cringe inducing moments, (particularly between Albedo and Shaltear) that I felt were unnecessary and even somewhat annoying. Only However, there were many great moments that made up for them.


The game world was presented brilliantly – the exposition relating to Nazarick in particular was excellent. The parts of the world that were featured heavily in the story were explored and developed, and the parts that weren’t retained a sense of mystery that kept things interesting.


There were a few brilliant battle scenes - some accompanied by exposition and some that were just pure action - but all were hugely enjoyable.


There was also a strategy element to this anime that was somewhat reminiscent of Log Horizon, but it wasn’t overused or particularly hard to follow. The MC being overpowered in this anime also felt natural and was pleasing rather than obnoxious (which it could easily have been if it had been dealt with differently). 


All in all, not fabulous, but again, it was the best ‘stuck in a game’ world I’ve seen yet. It was well done, but 8 was the best I could give because it didn’t evoke really any strong emotions in me when I was watching it (even though I was interested enough by the setting, plot and characters to keep watching). 


Obviously I’d recommend for fans of the genre, but also for those that enjoy comedy or action anime that are a little more on the intellectual side. XD

Overlord basically tells a story about this MMORPG named Yggdrasil that’s currently dying. And thus it ended the legend of Ainz Ooal Gown, the most well-known and powerful player in the game.
However, he notices that he can’t sign off and thus he gets trapped in this world. But soon enough he notices that the environment is different and his guild NPC turns to be real beings with emotions. 
I’m pretty sure most of us probably thinks that the story will surely enough be the same as of SAO, but I kid you not it’s a lot better and I mean a LOT Better.
Well, in Overlord,the protagonist is OP as crap, but in a way that is believable. I mean if you play an MMORG like WoW and grind up a crap ton you could end up just like him. And the protagonist have been playing this game since it’s launching and never let go of it till the very end. He’s like those people you see in the leaderboards ranking number 1 all the time. Different from shows like Sword Art Online, that makes a story of “redemption and revenge” into this “Fan service 100%”. Overlord plot inherent a sense of originality where it’s fun to see the MC as this Over Powered person but also, believable. He plays the role of almost as an antagonist, who have the world in his hands. He can overthrow anyone and it’s fun to see how he can shaped the world as their Overlord.


The shows main pros are it’s character development. Every move that Ainz took defines his character as a person who knows every single detail about RPGs or we could call a Tryhard. And when he thinks of an idea, a plan of action he thinks very thoroughly on his plans, he knows the consequences of his every move and can handle everything on his own accord. Also not to mention, the other characters are also loveable and we could invest a lot for each character. The show also have a sense of comedy in a sense that no one knows about The MC’s OPness in the new world. 


The Art and OST of the show went well together and really dynamically show, the shows potential. 


Overall I enjoy the anime and it’s considered as an anime that I could think again as a really enjoyable show. That delivers a clear story and direction, the plot is easy to understand and in a sense we could imagine ourselves as the Overlord, that could take over the world.

Aside from the occasional addition of unrealistic animations, overlord really has no major flaws. 
With its amazing and atmospheric soundtracks, interesting characters and great use of logic over emotion (emphasized with the main character being undead), it manages to take the milked concept of putting an ordinary person into a fantasy world, and excel where other shows like SAO couldn't. 
It would be a stretch to say that Overlord is an original series, but that was likely never the intention of the author. Instead Overlord is a response to the already well established concept of Isekai, but with some twists which puts it above manyof its predecessors.

Overlord is the next in the series of novels where people are trapped in video games to be made into an anime. The story of Overlord is about Momonga, who almost immediately renames himself to Ainz Ooal Gown, who is online in a game called Yggdrasil at the last moment that the game is going to go offline. However, he is still there once the servers are supposed to go down and he finds himself in another world with everything that was in his castle at the time. In this new world of swords and magic, there are elements from Yggdrasil, but also elements thatare not. There, Ainz begins his search for what the heck is going on.


The art of Overlord is very impressive and there are times when it feels like it is the quality of an OVA instead of just an anime series. The only downside to the animation is that sometimes, the skill effects look out of place because some are made with computer effects and have a bit of 3D whereas others fit in like standard animation. It creates a bit of inconsistency.


The opening theme of the series is fairly generic fast and loud guitar and song about power. The ending theme is similar, but more with Albedo and lyrics about love and obsession, which matches her character, but still sort of feels out of place like the opening theme. Had the music in the show itself adopted a similar style during even combat, it could have at least been more consistent. This greatly contrasts the fantasy setting that it is going for when the towns often play lighter music that sounds like it's from a banjo. However, the music that often goes into the Great Tomb of Nazarick matches its atmosphere and theme. If the series had been more consistent with its music, it might have been a lot better.


A big weakness in Overlord is the lack of proper character development. The entire story is pushed by the fact that Ainz does not know what is going on and attempts to do so, but we do not learn much more about him or his previous life. He just accepts things as is and hopes to seek out anyone else from Yggdrasil. Each of the Floor Guardians of Nazarick have their own personality and theme, but also do not change. They are all driven by their love of their masters and do little on screen but swear their loyalty with only a few exceptions. Each of those characters are supposed to have been programmed by members of Nazarick with complete character profiles and programming, but we never really get to see this.


If you enjoy a standard Shounen series or something like Sword Art Online and Log Horizon, you will enjoy Overlord. The main character is absurdly powerful to the point where anytime he or his companions enters combat, he just rolls his way forward destroying everything. For comparison, most trained soldiers are like at a level 20 range, the main character is close to 100 and can summon creatures that are considered to be legendary to the local population. However, the fights are not the focus of the series though there are a few epic ones. The focus is on the world and learning about it and a little more of the world is explored with each story arc. If you are hoping for character development and an eventual escape by Ainz back to his world, then you might want to skip this. If you want to see what happens when the most powerful being ever to exist ends up in another world, then Overlord might be worth giving a try.

First of all, stop comparing every single mmorpg-based series with Sword Art Online. It's not only irritating, it is also incomparable.
If you want to compare Overlord to a "similar" you should compare it more to Log Horizon, where you know that the protagonist is trapped but know nothing or little about him from his past on real life, neither how the game was actually based upon.
This isn't a survival game plot. The story tells about someone who got trapped on a world he liked more than the real life, but nobody plays it anymore. Story follows some interesting aspects, like the change of personality andthe "tense situation control" on which an aura forces him to stay calm.


The thing I liked the more about this anime is probably the character design, as the story gets twisted throughout the episodes, but in the end, gets somewhat solid and ready for a new season.


It's a great anime if you like to reach more deeply how getting "trapped" inside a mmorpg would end up like, protagonist affection with his old guild mates, behavioural change to adapt his new character, etc. 


Please don't even think about comparing it with SAO.

Story 8/10 - Overall the story was somewhat original with the MC being stuck in a video game being done a little differently than most of the anime from its genre, so that's nice to see. The only real problems I had with the story was that the whole Shalltear thing came into the story at a weird time, and it had me a little disinterested at first, but that story picked up, and by the end I was having more fun.

Sound 7/10 - The score would be a bit higher if the soundtrack drew me in more, but when i did take a listen to it while watching the episode it sounded pretty good, but it didn't managed to get too big of a reaction from me.


Character 7/10 - Most of the characters i liked, i just wish that they would've been a little more fleshed out, but other than that the characters were at least somewhat enjoyable ( except Clementine..she creeps me out).


Enjoyment 8/10- Most of the time I really enjoyed watching Ains' journey as well as watching the side characters do their thing, which i honestly wanted to happen more than it did..no offence to Ains-sama. On the other hand it was a show I could just multi-task with 

( which i did several times), and overall it was a pretty enjoyable ride.


Overall - 8/10
