Let me confess one thing: I actually watched and finished Sword Art Online, except that you can't find it anywhere my list. Meanwhile, you can find titles like Date-A Live and Infinite Stratos, and even hackneyed things like Himouto Umaru-chan and Glasslip. Now why is that?
The answer is simple: I expected Date-A and IS to be harem-y and I know what I was gonna get and that's what I got (both exceeded my low-bar expectations anyway as I learned to acknowledge them both). Himouto and Glasslip, I expected them to be, well, hackneyed. 
But when I watched SAO, I expected it to be RPG-fantasy-brilliant. It'sthe kind of expectation where let's say, I expect that the Ford Mustang to have a growling V8---but now that they also put an inline-4 engine under its hood as part of their "EcoBoost" lineup, it turned disappointing. 


Sorry SAO-fans, but after knowing and playing Final Fantasy and the TRUE RPG games of PS1 such as LegendofMana, L.o.Legaia, Lo.Dragoon, Grandia, Alundra and those kinda, SAO has to live up to that, which it didn't. Instead, SAO was flaunting more of Kirito's moods and his inevitable harem and Asuna's armpits. That's what I mean about disappointment, and that's what SAO went for me, it simply lacked the RPG quality and poked the harem genre in it, thus I don't want it on my list.


However, here's OVERLORD, which I could say according to my metaphor, is the Ford Mustang Shelby GT350 with that overpowering 5.2L V8, fit for an overlord alright.



STORY = 8

Straight away, this is quite the problem though. How the storyline was created kinda is, I admit, lacking in complexity...or should we wait for season 2? The RPG essence is there, make no mistake, but as to the messing up the fantasy world with a whole lot of thundagas and blizzagas, chaos and madness, it was all brief. But what I happily regard this is 8 is once you've watched this and you know what RPG stands for, you're entirely familiar with the magic spells and "gameplay", and this wins the hearts of true-RPG fans like me. We know, we simply know how emotions go to venture in a world that feels like Fa'Diel.



ART = 10

Obviously.



SOUND = 10

Both opening and ending songs are simply rockatronic, just like how Japan used to make RPG BGMs with electric guitar riffs and adlibs, and not the keyboard-bound chimes nowadays.

Seiyuu-wise, I only know that Shalltear is voiced by Dekomori--I instantly recognized her voice and Sumire Uesaka's charm resonated, that's it---I didn't bother knowing more seiyuus knowing Dekomori's around.



CHARACTERIZATION = 6

This is perhaps the strong point but it's what I do expect if the main character, Momonga, is mighty. He has his mindset for conquering his newfound world. He has his "press R1" backup of non-playable characters aka. Guardians. He decides his party depending per quest, per episode bluntly stated, and the adventure begins as nonchalantly as racing the Mustang against a Prius. You know it's "too much powerful", you know it won't lose.

This turned out because the story began when Lord Momonga was already on level 99, of course, with the premise stated with concise and short flashbacks that he did start as weak, or was on low-level then way back. 

I have my qualms about "too much powerful" characters because they're only a wrong execution away from being a garystu/marystu, but because of the RPG-feels, I can't be bothered by it, subjectively. 

Objectively though, is the reason I gave it a 6 because whenever I review here in MAL, I always separate my mental from my emotional takes. But as its plot made overpowerful characters forgivable, then they're nowhere near the realm of garystu/marystu because the plot and elements already evaded just that, and didn't pay the price.



ENJOYMENT = 8

Honestly I did enjoy it, thanks to the RPG feels. :) Some dragging events pulled down a -2, but that can be overlooked.



OVERALL = 7

Again, I metaphorically compared Overlord to the Ford Mustang Shelby GT350 V8, now why a 7? 

The thing is, it's got to do with my [car] preference. Take a look at this very Mustang: it's overly Shelby-powerful and you know what that means: a 5.2L V8 526HP spitting monster, it's all about speed and acceleration; and thanks to that, it has no backseats, no air-condition. The luxuries are sacrificed for the sake of saving weight. Sorry Mustang fans, speed is not everything for me as buying those cars means indulging; and that goes to other weight-saving supercars like the Ferrari 458 Speciale and the McLaren P1, I ain't a fan of those, too.

That's particularly how I viewed Overlord for the metaphorical car-anime comparison. In RPG-terms. Overlord is grand, the plot is well-made, the characters are well-thought, but somehow having too-powerful characters made the story a bit dull (only One Punch Man succeeded pulling out of this). It's like playing RPGs with cheats of all-items-unlocked and max-level sorts. You know you're going to win, hence you know it's going to be boring unless you're a child.


I expected Overlord to be RPG and it delivered my expectations just fine, it made me feel the feels back on PS1 RPG days, but the overpowering trait is also an expectation I know I'm not preferring to. And thus, it turned out to be 7 overall.

But that's on me, I, who greatly respects the TRUE RPGs of PS1. My probably biased-perspective emitted out from those.



VERDICT: Rest assured, if you're one who is playing PS2 and PS3 RPG games, or someone who haven't been introduced to RPG, or someone who is looking for a not necessarily 10 but still is a well-made anime, Overlord is your ticket.

If you're on the otherwise, then consider looking at SAO's Asuna's armpits.

Overlord is a very complicated show to talk about because, on the face of it, it is one of the best anime series release we've had in years... the plot is a twist on the modern cliche of "Guy in MMORPG world", placing the main character effectively as one of the villains with an army of minions already set-up. The plot is actually very well thought-out and some of the action scenes, though simplistic, are absolutely fantastic.
And yet it is one of the most deeply flawed anime I have ever seen... due to something that is rarely taken into consideration when reviewing/viewing an anime series;The direction. This anime has, quite possibly the worst director I have ever seen. Some scenes drag way too long, other scenes are cut absurdly short depriving the viewer for crucial information (Repeat viewings reveal this to be quite egregious). The pacing of the story is very poor, there are several episodes where barely anything happens at all, and others where the story is so drastically rushed that they set up an entire major story arc and many subplots in a single episode , making for a disjointed, incoherent mess (Ex: Episode 10 and 11 are a perfect example of what I am talking about).


I know this is a strange complaint to make, but directing is one of those things that you only really notice if it went horribly wrong and in this case, it went horribly wrong. It has some fabulous scenes and sequences that are perfectly paced and executed, but these are very rare and sandwiched in between a lot of awful choices. For example, there is a scene somewhat early on where there is a huge setup for a massacre against some mages... but when the time comes for the actual massacre to occur, it just smash cuts to them walking back to base. What actually happened? who knows.


Conversely, some great examples are the end scene fade-out during a major fight towards the end of the series (You'll know it when you see it) and a slow moving murder that is absolutely beautiful. These are rare but precisely because of their rarity, they stand out a great deal.



So let's move on to a more traditional reviewing style now that the major flaw is done;



CHARACTER:

The characterization is very poor. There is very little character development for any of people we follow with the sole exception of the eponymous Overlord. Ironically, there are tertiary characters that get more development than most of the primary cast (Narberal Gamma, Nphirea Balear and Demiurge) which should tell you right there how little we get to know any of the main characters/how flat they are.


The thing is, there is a wealth of substance here with all of these characters ... but because of the poor directing, very little comes across. A lot of pivotal characters are portrayed as one-note and dull (Ex: Albedo, Cocytus, Aura/Mare, Shalltear Bloodfallen, etc.). But as I keep saying, there is a lot here, but it was just poorly executed.




STORY:

The story is executed very haphazardly, the reason for this is that it is adapting the story arcs from the Overlord novel, jumping from one to the other with very little setup and often times with very little pay off.


A young man with a fairly bad life is somehow trapped in a game world. The entire plot revolves around him exploring the game world very cautiously looking for other humans rather than the NPCs he is surrounded by. There is not much in the way of a unifying thread , but that's fine... the whole season is basically world-building, setting up location, characters and establishing strengths, this is very good... the problem is, a lot of these things are done poorly. I'd hate to sound repetitive, but the bad direction makes it difficult to get a good grasp on where each location is and what the internal politics of the region are.


Basically, there is no story, it is just world-building... but it is a very clear setup for a greater story to come. If there is a season 2, it will use the established story base to launch into a potentially epic storyline, we will see.






ENJOYMENT:

There is a lot to be said for a main character that is depicted as actually being intelligent. It is so rare that when you see this series, you might not even catch how careful and calculated all of his actions are. Add to that the , frankly, irresponsible levels of fanservice-y scenes and you have a great combination. I would say I loved everything about this series except for most of the fight scenes.


The variety in characters, the surprisingly clever dialogues and actions made it a treat to watch.




OVERALL:

The terrible direction absolutely buries a fantastic show. The voice actors are clearing giving it their all, the animation while not good, is at least helped by wonderful art. The story and its twists are quite original and the general tone of the show shifts quickly but is pulled off masterfully (The one thing the director got right). 


If you are a fan of the current cliche  "Guy trapped in video game world", this is for you.

If you want to see a main character actually make subtle, but very intelligent actions, this is for you.

If you like non-sexual video game fanservice, this is for you.

If you want a complex , overarching epic story, this is NOT for you.



Though this is now one of my favorite animes, I cannot deny that it is deeply flawed... if it has a season 2, it will probably be legendary, but as it stands, the first season suffers from too many issues for me to give a broad recommendation.

I wish to explain my rating of this show before I go on to a short review; Overlord is the sum of its parts. No aspect of it goes beyond what I would rate 7/10, as budget limitations, a sort of wish-fulfillment nonsense aspect of the story (I'm looking at you, Albedo) and sometimes drawn-out scenes will have its clear effect on the product. However! As none of these aspects are especially weak, together they carry Overlord to greater heights!
I am going to break this show down to show you what I mean.
Story 8/10:
Sort of standard isekai plot here - young guy in a fantasygame ends up in a fantasy world with his overpowered abilities and seemingly endless stash of super-items and in this case even a whole set of powerful servants, two of which are attractive females who are enamored with him.


There's a twist which does make a huge difference here - he's evil. Or rather, he's supposed to be, as an Undead wizard that quickly loses a lot of his human compassion (though hints of his humanity remaining seem to be there) and take steps to spread his name. He's saved as a protagonist by being more evil in his logic than his actions though, as it seems he will rationalize good deeds by stating their long-term gain to perplexed (evil) servants.


I believe there is a comment being made about how one is shaped by one's surroundings and also how truly intelligent people will be benevolent, only greedy to a point and quick to protect others - as long term gain comes out of social harmony and not 'law of the jungle'-stuff that produces resentment and vengeance. A thoughtful subtlety, not overly obvious, is a plus in my book.


The story gets pretty dark at times without shying away from tragedy, despite the wish fulfillment-aspect of Overlord, which I believe deserves another nod of respect.


Art 7/10:

Budget-restrictions are clearly in place here, but they really did a good job with what they did use. There is some 3D in here that looks better than in much newer shows and the interaction between 2D parts and 3D is actually pretty solid (remember the bone dragons and the fight in the graveyard?). Sometimes there will be clear shortcuts but overall it feels pretty balanced. Consistently decent animation blended with a good mix of dark and bright colors depending on the time of day and environment would, to me, indicate a knowledge in how to use a budget.


Sound 7/10:

I am honestly not a sound guy, so I'm mostly going by gut feeling here. I felt like most sounds did what they needed to do, at one point there was a lack of music, giving an eerie vibe which I felt did justice to the moment. There is a metal element to the show's intro and outro songs which feels pretty cool, calling to the fore the mutual history of metal and fantasy. The voice actors do a good job and knows how to express a lot with small fluctuations in volume and tone.


Character 7/10:

As I mentioned earlier, we have a main character that loses his humanity and becomes a pretty cold creature. You still root for and sympathize with him as he is obviously not as 'evil' as one would think, considering his ghoulish appearance. His journey of self-discovery only starts in season 1 but not having seen the sequel seasons, I find it promising. His cadre are mostly pretty simplistic characters, but I'm sure they will get further development as is usually the case in these types of multi-character stories. The side characters outside of his group are surprisingly well-structured. You get to see minor characters return seemingly out of nowhere but with good and consistent reasons. I find that exhilarating, having seen a lot of crap that will introduce characters for throwaway lines before they enter the Garden of Could Have Been.


Enjoyment 8/10:

Needing to immediately start the next episode, being excited despite knowing who is going to win the fight four times out of five and hoping minor characters are going to be saved but having those hopes dashed... it really works. I enjoy things are somewhat unpredictable and well-executed. Smart dialogue isn't bad. And Overlord is the cake to both keep and eat in that sense.


Overall 8/10:

I believe Overlord deserves such a strong grade mostly because of how much I enjoy it. It is definitely biased, but a qualitative line of reasoning as well - if you can submit to some harmless and dumb fan service (I can stand rolling my eyes a couple of times without having to hammer out my anger on Twitter, unlike a few peeps) then there is a plethora of powerful scenes, cool action and interesting strategical maneuvering in Overlord for the fantasy/politic-persuasion of anime viewers.


Also those ridiculous names make me laugh out loud.


Ains Ooal Gown.

There are many concepts here that I like, but I would like them to be done better, and with possibly a bigger budget cause the CG (while not bad but there is a lot) still takes away from how good this can be. I also think the show is pacing way too slow for my taste, they have to dominate the world but they've only seen one city and one town by the end of the season. I know they want to do more seasons but its still too slow. But I'm hopeful with this shows popularity that future seasons have a bigger budget andjust take out the insane amount of CG. I also hope that there will be more world building in the upcoming seasons. All that said, I'm down to watch some more.

Going into this season I didn't really know what to expect but at the same time I was kinda excited. Prior to this there was only one anime I've watched that was about gaming, and that was the popular SAO. SAO was a series that I found to be very overrated and while it didn't suck it ruined its concept that I initially thought was great. Like many I'm a person who enjoys video games and watching anime that take place in one is an idea that I hope can work well. Overlord is a title that I've been hearing recently so I wanted togive it a try. I was excited for this series for two main reasons; 1)it's a seinen meaning it's mature and dark and I like anime with darkness, 2) and it's done by the legendary Studio Madhouse. There are so many well done anime I've heavily enjoyed that were done by this studio examples being Death Note, Monster, Hellsing Ultimate, HxH, and One-Punch Man. So that being said does this season give Overlord a hot intro into the video game genre ??***contains MINOR spoilers***



Story:7/10

A generic plot with a cool and interesting twist. The story starts off like SAO where the mc gets trapped within the game and he either has to return to his real world or discover how it happened. However watching this from a villain perspective is where we get something new and refreshing. Lord Ainz the protagonist is what drives the plot here, most of the story's reliance is on his characterization and getting used to his new world. That being said the anime's setting is so awesome and it really gives you that video game vibe. World building overall is very good as it discovers other villages and areas and how it feeds off its characters. But better yet there's more room for exploration and due to its cool environments it leaves the viewer to wanna learn more of it. There's also a nice balance of action, comedy, and fan service. As anime fans we know that fan service can be used so heavily to the point of insanity but here it's used very well and it's not too distracting or excessive. What let me down here was the pacing, at times the story could really drag. For example whenever the plot shift away from Ainz it actually becomes pretty boring. In terms of story and plot progression it honestly did very little as like I said earlier it's main focus was Lord Ainz trying to fit in his new world. The season's conclusion also kinda ended on a weak note but knowing the series is far from over if gives its story plenty of chances later on.   


Art:9/10

What's strange here is that while the animation in general was good, it still felt underwhelming. I'm so used to Madhouse giving us near perfect animation but in this series I couldn't say the same. There was a lot more CGI here than I anticipated and while it didn't look bad it wasn't fantastic looking either. Now don't get me wrong I understand that 2015 was a busy year for the studio so it probably meant that they weren't able to give this series their all. Where the animation really stood out tho was during its action where the magic spells are casted. I was also extremely impressed with how well they exaggerated facial expression to the characters particularly in episode 9. The magic spell effects were fantastic  and it really gave me this great video game vibe whenever there was an action sequence. The art however was even better with many awesome looking character designs. The multiple outfits Lord Ainz wore looked so cool and there was never a time he didn't look badass. A bunch of the side characters were given great detail although since some are cross dressers it was hard to tell their gender. The series visually is brilliantly filled with bright colors and in game scenery that left much to be desired.


Sound:9/10

I was once again impressed and satisfied in this area like I usually am with Madhouse. I absolutely adore the opening and ending themes here. The opening song "Clattanoia" was very catchy and with good lyrics that described the show's world well. My favorite however was the ending song "L.L.L." it was mad epic and awesome to the point where it's been stuck in my head for a while recently. The background tracks were great as well as it had dark undertones that set the moods very well at times. Like most Madhouse projects there's a lot of rock music here and although Im not a huge rock fan I've always like OSTs the studio brought to their anime. My main problem with the music however is that it had a bad habit of drowning some of the dialogue and it did ruin some moments but not a whole lot. The sound effects were also solid something Im used to studio Madhouse excelling at. Both Japanese and English dubs did good here as well. Satoshi Hino and Chris Guerrero did great as Lord Ainz respectively with Hino's lighter tone nailing Ainz's comedy and Guerrero's gruffer voice fitting the badassery more. To answer which dub is better I'll give the edge to the Japanese but in the end it's really up to personal preference.


Character:8/10

An enjoyable cast with high potential and a dominate lead. The main protagonist Ainz Ooal Gown is easily the standout here as he's given a lot of focus. What makes him so interesting is how he battles his inside and outside personalities. On the outside he's this badass OP overlord with a dark commanding presence but on the inside he's a mere human who for a specific reason is scared to make allies. His character gives us a fun, cool, yet likable character that's almost impossible to get bored of. He also has great interaction scenes with other characters like the loyal yandere beauty Albedo who makes him uncomfortable and this leads to humorous scenes. The supporting characters have a lot of different personalities which adds variety to the cast. However what most of them have in common is their strict loyalty to Ainz which is so great to watch. It's also cool asf to see some of them are capable of kicking ass in battle like Nabe who's one of my favorites. And while most of them weren't given tons of development they are all complex enough to make you want to learn more about them in the future. I was hoping the villains/antagonists were a bit better tho. They weren't given enough insight to me and most of them came across as rather bland. For example there's this hot female named Clementine and she was portrayed as a sadist but outside of that she was nothing else. This is something I hope the series would improve in future seasons.



Final Verdict


Pros


+Story uses a more interesting and new take on a overused genre that make it different

+An awesome main lead that cool, likable, and downright joy to watch at all times

+Some great looking action that feature brutality that emphasizes the series' maturity   

+Side characters are very fun and have rooms of potential

+While mature and dark, the series can at times be funny and good use of fan service


Cons


-Pacing can be off, does little in terms of story progression

-Animation is a bit disappointing with a lil too much CGI effects

-Some bland villains that weren't given a lot of depth



Personal Favorites



Characters: Ainz, Albedo, and Nabe


Arc: The Dark Warrior


Fight: Ainz vs Clementine



Season 1 of Overlord gets off to a solid start. It has a very fun cast that's room for improvement and a great lead that's badass, op, yet likable, and relatable at the same time. It also has an epic soundtracks with great character designs and good yet somewhat underwhelming animation. What's cool about Overlord is that it's not just a gaming series it's also a dark fantasy and a issekai anime. I'd be lying if I said I wasn't excited to see how this series ends cuz imo the potential is through the roof. Im not tryna compare here but it's first season was a lot better than SAO's if u ask me. I was obviously mad late getting into this series and just like that I can watch the next two seasons w/o having to wait!!



Sub or Dub Recommendation: Sub

I stumbled upon this anime a long time ago only to forget about it until this last summer. I read that this anime was meant to be only one season and created purely to promote and sell the manga. However, the amount of support it got was overwhelming that the creator continued with the anime. For continuity/story sake it is only natural for some things to get cut or changed around for it to make sense to the watcher who hasn't read the manga. Even so, I cannot praise this anime enough! The Story and world building is outstanding and very deep for an anime.The art however due to an animation budget suffers at times with its CGI but sometimes makes scenes better - it's a difficult balancing act, and is up to personal preference. Other than that minor compliant this is a great anime. My only warning for newer viewers, again especially if you're an anime only watcher. Pay attention to everything in the sub, season 1 in particular is huge information dump and missing one sentence of information can easily make it hard to follow later on. If you have ever played an RPG, give this anime a try!

Overlord is probably the most chuunibyo series that I’ve ever seen and despite the reviews you may see on MyAnimeList, I believe that it’s worse than Sword Art Online. I’m not sure whether this series was supposed to be purely a gag/comedy series, but if that was the point, it had nothing but dry coughs emitting from my throat at how juvenile, light novel that whole thing was. 
	• The beginning of the series seemed to have promise, with a main character being trapped in a game with characters that his friends had programmed. But, the show never really emphasizes on the struggles of beingtrapped in a video game or gives any of the characters any identity crises involving the fact that their entire personalities are scripted by people, instead of them being unique individuals.


	• But, I suppose a character wouldn’t realize that their personality was all wired, just as us humans inquire about genetics and God. Aside from me justifying that point, I wish all of the characters hadn’t felt so empty. The protagonist is pretty much straight out of a self-insert fan-fiction. 


	• Albedo, one of his servants, is obsessed with him and thirsts for him constantly, because that’s what her pre-established purpose in the world is. All of the servants, in fact, constantly praise the main character, when in reality, he’s probably a scrawny programmer or something.


	• There are some interesting character designs and traits, such as: a loli vampire in a video game world getting a boob job, a miserly servant with with diamond sphere eyes, and a nazi that looks like it came out of Pink Floyd’s The Wall. Wait, what?


	• This is what I hate about light novels. They don’t form a cohesive plot and instead write anything and everything that they think looks cool or comes to them in some delusional drug binge. Everything in Overlord seemed retconned to shit and back. There was no severity about anything and since they’re characters in a video game, they can just re-spawn. 


	• The best part of the series were the designs, except for the weird maid bunny girl, fuck that; the voice acting was top-tier, I was especially impressed with the voice actress that did Madoka Kaname doing the most demented voice  that I think I’ve ever heard on a character, and, well, that’s it. I mean, Albedo’s hot.


	• Overall, Overlord is not something that is worth accolades and an eight average on MyAnimeList. It’s pretty much pandering chuuni garbage that will make any well-adjusted adult cringe upon watching. I give Overlord, the first season, a 2/10.

A guy becomes trapped in an MMORPG and wonders what to do with himself. He has a huge guild citadel filled with powerful gear and an army of incredibly loyal and overpowered NPCs. Momonga decides that he will spread his guild name across the land in hopes that anyone who previously knew him in the game will seek him out. Momonga is a lonely office worker so I guess he doesn't care about going home, though this is not really discussed at all. 
The rules of the world are very unclear. Momonga and his castle are teleported to a new land, which is generically medieval,and all of the so-called NPCs just act like regular humans including Momonga's servants. There are occasional mentions of classes and skills but it isn't any different from people shouting out their ability names before attacking in any other anime. According to Momonga, some things work the same way as in his MMO, and some things don't. There are no flashbacks to Momonga playing the game in the past so we just have to take his word for it. Usually it just works as an excuse for Momonga to pull out random scrolls and spells that can do whatever he wants them to. 


The show follows Momonga embarking on minor quests to gain information about the new world and get some cash. Momonga is vastly more powerful than anyone else he encounters, so everything pretty much amounts to: a villain or monster appearing, the NPCs gasping in horror, Momonga killing it with ease and then everyone being amazed. It's kind of jarring because everything is setup with suspenseful music and timing as though the event is actually supposed to be dramatic and impressive, but the audience is already fully aware that there's nothing on the line. There is absolutely zero progression on the story itself, we have no further information about why or how any of this happened in the last episode than at the start. 


The cast of NPCs commanded by Momonga are well-designed and the art is of a high-quality. You will probably see a few of them that pique your interest. There isn't really any reason for them to all be demonic creatures but it does feel fresh. It would have been nice to see the story have more development for these NPCs, instead we mostly meet random new characters in the cities that Momonga travels to. The people he meets are actually interesting characters, it's just made clear that they will not be very important to the story as a whole so you become a little reluctant to invest in them.


Morals is something I wish the show would discuss a little more. Sometimes Momonga has no problems killing people, other times he becomes attached to people and is concerned for them. Sometimes he considers letting bad things happen to look better when he saves the day, and other times he talks about justice and helping others. Momonga has no idea if he is just killing NPCs or not as things are clearly not the same as his MMO world, so I would really expect him to mull more over the implications for his behaviour. 


Overall the production value seems high and it can keep your interest most of the way. However I think this is because the themes grab your interest and you are holding on for some development and to see where it goes. But it doesn't go anywhere. It's literally just watching a guy stuck in a video game fuck around and do what he wants. Everyone either fears him or loves him, it does occasionally seem like an indulgent fanfiction for the author.

This review encompass season 1, 2, and 3.  
The thing that bothers me most about the show is the main character.  If the wish fulfillment bullshit was absent in the show I think it would be a jolly good time.  Nothing particularly deep or well written, but with fun action, a neat world to explore, and interesting characters to meet.  
The main character is by far the worst thing in this show.  All his faults can be boiled down to two points.
1.  The way the NPC's interact with him.  Re-writing the main hot chick to love you isstupid and cringy.  But the worst thing about it is its totally unnecessary, since all of the female NPC's, even the male ones sometimes, want the MC's dick anyways.  Adding this only serves to make the MC out to be a complete weirdo, which IS the point of his character, but it messes the whole dynamic of the show up for me.  Since every character already acts like this, it ONLY serves to taint my opinion of the MC and the Albedo.  Her whole character is just devoted to being in love with MC, and MC just becomes a creep. 


I have a problem with this because it ruins a theme that could actually be really interesting to explore, which they hint at.  And that is the dynamic between creator and creation.  Having the NPC's love the MC because he helped create them and then stayed with them when all of the other guild members left is a really cool idea.  Especially if they found out what Ains is really like.  That hes not the "overlord" but just some nerd.  I think that could be really fun, and heartwarming.  For them, it would be accepting that their creator is a weirdo, and for him allowing himself to show his true side.  But that is all ruined by the fact that albedo is demoted to being just a slave with a sole personality trait that every other character has anyways. 


2.  Ains is fucking boring.  I like the joke that this guy does not know what hes doing.  I genuinely think its funny.  But just imagine, if he was allowed to have emotions on top of it.


It boggles my mind that this guy is not allowed to have emotions by some bullshit green lights.  I simply cannot wrap my head around the justification for restricting him to being generic and vaguely evil.  


Just imagine, Ains being allowed to react in a way that might get him into some hot water.  Like he gets embarrassed by some social interaction and he has to justify it to the people loyal to him.  He could pull out some BS, make it out to be a positive, and everybody would love him for it.  This happens already, but just at the absolute base level, and without much of Ains' input at all.


When the joke stops being funny, you can pull back the veil, and you can do the interesting character stuff from my last point.  I think that would be great.  As it stands now hes just a boring, husk of a character.  Again, they hint at this concept, allowing us to hear his inner thoughts.  But actually allowing him to stumble, then try to pick himself up would be 10x better.



The rest of the show is pretty alright.  Season 2 onward raised this show from a 3 to a 5, with its emphasis on other characters besides Ains.  


The world and characters are pretty fun to learn about, its just a shame the main character drags the whole thing down so much.

STORY
The origins and background are extremely sloppy. A lot of details are left unexplained. Another RPG game-based anime. Would have been better if the world is real. It seems the player of the game is trapped. The servers didn't shut down the game but transported them somewhere else. The character does not seem to have logged off his account since then so it does not make any sense at all. In other words, I'll reiterate how the background of the story remained sloppy and unexplained. However, the flow is alright and makes it watchable after a few episodes.
ART
Nothing special. Generic art with a lot offlashy animations.


SOUND

SFX is good, although generic. However, the opening theme is good and resembles the Parasyte OP song. It complements the characters and the story.


CHARACTER

Good and somewhat memorable. A strong character figure that possesses kindness and wisdom. The feeling of Guts from Berserk resonates from the character. Although uses high levels of magic instead of brute strength. The main character also falls under a heroic villain category, at least there were hints in the last episode. Other than that, the rest of the characters are bland, and not memorable. 


ENJOYMENT

The first few episodes were boring and horrible. But the storytelling improved thereafter. Cliffhangers were properly executed which kept me watching at some point. 


SUMMARY


Story: 3

Art: 5

Sound: 7

Character: 6

Enjoyment: 6


Overall, generic, sloppy, and could have been better. It is still watchable and the story will keep you somewhat curious if you can get over the fact that the beginning is sloppy.

The anime tells the tale of what becomes of the last remaining player of Yggdrasil, the hugely popular Dive Massively Multiplayer Online Role Playing Game (“DMMORPG”), after the game serves shut down. The last player, Momonga, was the guild leader of Ainz Ooal Gown, one of the strongest guilds within the game, which consisted of 41 members. Upon the cessation of the Yggdrasil, Momonga finds himself still trapped within the game, unable to utilise the normal player functions to contact other players or quit the game. Thus, he takes on the name Ainz Ooal Gown as a message to other Yggdrasil players, who may bestuck in game like him, and begins to explore the new world that he is trapped in.


Overlord shares many similarities with other anime, such as Sword Art Online, wherein a player becomes trapped within a game and must work to solve the mystery behind their imprisonment. The anime’s plot is interesting and relies heavily on the characterisation of Ainz Ooal Gown (“Lord Ainz”), who is portrayed as the supreme overlord with unparalleled power and strength. Due to his immense power, there is some similarity between Lord Ainz and Saitama from the anime, One Punch Man, who also was ridiculously powerful that no one stood a chance to defeat him.


Despite being a supreme overlord who is incredibly impressive, his mere presence commanding power and respect at every turn, Lord Ainz is likeable and illustrates his love and compassion for his guardians and servants, along with a kindness that one would not expect from such a powerful being. It is both amusing and eye-opening, the way his guardians and servants pledge to remain loyal to him to the bitter end and long to be in his company. The odd ‘love’ one of his guardians has for him makes for some humorous and oftentimes uncomfortable moments.


Along with characteristics which portray ultimate power, Lord Ainz’s appearance also speaks volumes of his abilities. With such a bold and domineering presence, it’s no wonder that he was chosen to be the supreme overlord of the guild. It’s also no surprise that his guardians and servants all fawn over him, desperate to serve their great and powerful master.


While similar to Sword Art Online, watching the anime did bring about a longing to jump into games like World of Warcraft or The Witcher, having been hyped up via the anime. Thankfully, each episode ends brilliantly, leaving us wanting more from the story and desperate to know the truth about why Lord Ainz became trapped.


The battle scenes are incredible, with brilliant sword fights and magic duels, which are followed by epic music. Watching Lord Ainz use his abilities to defeat those who we believe might be stronger than him is enchanting and magnificent. It’s extremely satisfying to be kept in suspense right to the very end, which is exactly how Overlord progresses. 


Visually, Overlord is filled with bright colours, brilliant animations and an in-game scenery that leaves much to be desired. The various armour and attire worn by Lord Ainz is magnificent, as are that of his guardians. It is slightly peculiar though that the Dark Elf siblings are depicted as cross-dressers, though this is no way a judgement of any kind. Rather, it was simply unexpected and was confusing initially to uncover which one was female and which male. That being said, both were undeniably adorable yet over-powered in their own right.


The soundtrack was as epic as the series itself, with dark undertones that set the mood of the anime. However, despite the catchy soundtrack and incredible music, it was disappointing that this music drowned out much of the dialogue of the anime, which made certain crucial moments inaudible.


After all, Overlord is a good watch, especially for fans of the isekai and action genre.

I don't want to write a long review for this anime, just because I know how skewed my view-point is.
I love Isekai (sent to another world) anime... even the bad ones.
But the only reason I did not rate this show higher, as well as the reason that I was inspired enough to write a review is because I just finished reading the Light Novels and the detail in the LN versus the anime made me rate it low.
I feel as though they could have taken a Log Horizon pace to the story and stretched it out, while still being interesting as well as more informativeof what is going on.\n\n
Really I just want to say that this is an anime that if you enjoy anti-heros and if you really love Isekai anime at all you should watch this with out a doubt.

Story: 10
Do you adore gothic style? Do you adore the death It self?!
Have you ever dreamed of becoming the death just once as a kid
and controlling an army when you were little with a little love added to It?
Then this anime is you!
Overlord, and Overlord II are full of strategic, and interesting performances.
You will definetely get addicted if you start watching this series.
Art: 9
The art/design in the anime seems very nice, they detailed every character out, and they even worked on characters that have nothing to do with Nazarick. The scenes that take place also seem very detailed. I liked the throne chamber's dark auraas It supposed to be in this anime.\n\n
Sound: 9\n
I really liked the openings of the anime, esspecially the second season's.\n
It already gets you the nice metal feeling that should be up for this anime introducing all the characters a bit. I think they worked pretty good on the extra voice sounds and the fighting ones really, so nobody could say that they didn't even try to do that :D\n\n
Characters: 10\n
Each character have a unique "feel" or description. You are instantly going to know who is who, and why do you remember him/her.\n
I don't want to go in to the details, but each character is different when also showing their loyality to Ains, and they also think different when It comes to fighting. I would even dare to say that I find these characters kinda unique, never really seen MOST of their behaviours in other animes.\n\n
Enjoyment: 10\n
I finished off the season 1 pretty quick, and went to S2 asap.\n
It's been a long time for me that an anime caught my attention like this,\n
I loved every episode in season 1, and even laughed at the "Dance of death" a lot. Those who had seen that moment already probably will think about me as a psycho from now on. \n\n
Overall: 10\n
If you watch this you won't regret It, esspecially if you adore gothic style / death as  I mentioned above. It's a unique anime, and there is a reason why It has 8+ out of 10 overall.

It's a pretty good anime and i would recommend anyone to watch. It starts strong with many questions asked which makes a good anime and finishes strong with internal conflict battle. It was quite badass.
Pros: Interesting relatable premises, good fight scenes.
Cons: A bit bleh, mediocre music.
It feels like an episodic series that is missing a ton of episodes 1 episode he couldn't access the "control panel" and the next everyone's using it. There was no big baddie this season i'm guessing it's an introduction to the series(imo that's a bad move). My own personal theory is the butler Sebas is the bad guy he looksshady as hell and he always has half his face(eyes) in shadow. Worth the watch yes, multiple watches no.

Have you ever wondered what it'd feel like to be the final boss of an RPG? Well, this anime delves into that situation.
First, let's look at how this series differ from other RPG-set series. For one, it doesn't explain how the MC dived into the game. There were no indication if he teleported or if it's all just a dream. Other than that, neither we or the MC know who's behind the complications found in that world, leaving us in suspense.
Also, the MC is introduced as two characters, but just one person. There's the unnamed protagonist who controls Ains, and Ains himself. From here, wesee two sides of the same coin, something that has not been explored before. Just the thought of having two characters being just one character makes you think how ingenious that idea is.


The art was... okay... It's not anything special. But the opening song was the first reason why I started watching this series. The lyrics fit the show perfectly!


Was it enjoyable? Personally, it was okay. If you're not into OP characters or RPG-like themed series, I wouldn't recommend it. So I suggest you get yourselves prepped before facing Overlord!

I recommend this anime to people who love ganking in MMORPG's. If ganking is not your thing, than for the love of god do not watch this anime!
Story 5/10
Overlord had a lot of potential. As you can read in the discription, Overlord is about the MMORPG Yggdrasil in which the main character gets stuck in said MMORPG. With his loyal servants he now plans to take over the world.
Everything in this description is true, except the part about taking over the world, which is the MOST IMPORTANT PART! I will not spoil anything for you, but this show is not about taking over the world.Its about the main character, together with his loyal servants, protecting and helping the minor settlements around his dungeon. He does this with the intent of eventually conquering the world but I think even you can agree that if there is no conquering going on, you can't really talk about the main character conquering the world, can you?


The story itself is pretty bland. There aren't any plot twists or psychological battles. Want to know why? Because the main character is overpowered. And not just a little overpowered. This guy kills everything in a single blow. He's like one punch man without the yellow suit. Because of this, there is never really any excitement. You never wonder if the main character is going to make it out alive, since you know he destroys everything on his path with effortless ease.


It's not all bad though. The story that is told, altough its not what you will expect, is fairly decent. The things that happen may grasp your attention enough so that you won't drop it before the final episode(as it did with me), but that is about it. For that reason, the story receives a 5 out of 10



Art 7 / 10


The art is pretty good. It's not amazing, but it's better than average. I can't really say a lot about this since the art isn't outstanding.


Sound 6 / 10


The battle music is pretty cool but overall I wouldn't listen to the OST of Overlord. Again, it's nothing special.


Characters 4 / 10


The characters are aweful in my opinion. I'm sorry for being so negative, but dear lord, they could have at least made the characters a little funnier. You won't really bond with the characters, except with the main character, who isn't interesting at all. He likes to reminisce about the good old days and is afraid of the women who adore him. He constantly complains about his surroundings and decides to lay low throughout the story even though he is the most powerful being in this MMORPG. It doesn't make any sense.


Most characters develop poorly and are not interesting at all. For that reason i give the characters a 4 out of 10


Enjoyment 5 / 10


I'm sure that there are people who enjoy this anime and there's nothing wrong with that. Like I said before, It's not aweful as there are some good parts in this anime, but they mean too little to me to make this anime a good one.


Overall 5 / 10


This anime could have been something great. It could have been about vast armies fighting each other with the main character and his servants leading the troops. Instead you get some boring story about one punch man laying low for a while. This anime is not for me and I DO NOT recommend this. Unless you love every anime that is about MMORPG's or if you like ganking, you will not like this one.

REVIEW WITH NO SPOILERS
Ok, first if you have watched Sword Art Online, it will be very simple to explain: Imagine if Kirito was a lot more overpower than he was, practicaly a God... and instead of other players, the other characters are NPCs. That's it. Recommend it.
But if you haven't seen Sword Art Online, then i will explain other way: The anime is about a man stuck in a game; in this game he is in the last level possible, so he is very strong, almost a God there. 
Then, he want to discover about this world that he is stuck, even though the worldis practically the same of the game he was playing. The protagonist is kind of dumb and choose very contestable ways to reach his goals...\n
The first episodes are very exciting, but this season was kind of a introduce for the universe. I'm very anxious for the next season because of the great potential of the work.\n
If you are looking for an adventure, not-reflective, entertain, but a not closed-story anime... this one is PERFECT!

Overlord! What you may perceive as another SAO on the community actually.... SAO. But, instead of a deus ex-machina, angelic, savior kind of Main Character, here we serve you...... guess what? an ANTAGONIST as the main character!!
He may seem like a good guy at first but believe me, he's a villain (or an anti-hero) at heart. This what makes Overlord different from the rest of the look-alike anime. The art is decent (The CGI is not too bad in my honest opinion) as expected of Madhouse. The OP is nice and the ED is nice as well. The VA is good for some character butnothing too special about it. The characters are well written and executed perfectly into the stories. Overall, this is a good anime but it was damn too short for my taste. If it was longer, I'll definitely give a 9/10

Ever see a man walk face first into a pole, or get tagged centimeters from home base? Maybe a bird going full tilt smack into a window? A child drop his ice cream?
That's what Overlord is. Its that feeling distilled and presented in color and sound.
The premise is simple. A nerd loser spends all his time playing video games as an escape from a complicated world. Suddenly his video game becomes real. But this isn't sword art online.
Initially he is elated but slowly his "escape" becomes a reality that is just as plagued with problems as his home life. He struggles to retain hisinnocence and humanity as he is figuratively (and literally) forced to become the monster he chose as his vehicle of escape. Its the epic of a man confronted with a crumbling dream. Except now, there is no escape to flee to. 


Its as if everyone was turned into the monsters they pretended to be on halloween. Sure being an undead is fun, for an evening. But for ever?


Watch as our dynamic and deep character experiences the love of another for the first time, only to realise that as an undead monster he cannot consummate it. Watch food turn to ash in his mouth. The warm rays of the sun burn him as children run form him in horror. He begins to go insane. Deep questions haunt the audience, will he succumb to his new identity? Or was he really a monster all along, his fantasy character a mere mask for the heartless murderer that lurked within? After all did he not CHOOSE to be an undead? Was his taking the mantle of the bad guy a cry for help? was it simply fun and games? Well it isn't a game now.



Thank God this awesome premise wasn't ruined with gothic lolita, harems and two dimensional enemies. Image what would have happened if a narcissistic idiot was in charge of this project. 

Would the interesting magical system be totally undermined by main characters that have such mastery of it they may as well be gods? Instead of seeing him have to consider politics for the first time, while confronting the new reality of a world that despises the sight of him, would we be shown huge anime tities flopping around? Would the plot have no connections? Would we scream bloody murder at the screen as yet another so called antagonist is swept away with pathetic ease? Would the author be so infatuated with his character that he can't bear to have him possesses any weakness at all? 

Would nothing matter in the end? The climax be pointless and utterly unfounded on the preceding episodes? Would every horrible anime trope rear its ugly head and lay waste the the best premise since fullmetal alchemist? 


Oh. Wait. That's exactly what happened. 


The anime tities are pretty good though. Nice and floppy. Should have just been hentai.

I know I'm going to get a lot of hate for this review right here. All the people saying that Overlord was a masterpiece, I'm not going to argue with you, however with me, the anime was dreadful for me watching it. In the first episode, the animation was so choppy for me that I literally wanted to puke. I'm unsure whether it was the server I was using or what, but it was utterly disgusting. The story was mediocre because, what am I supposed to say? Oh... A guy got stuck inside a VR game... that's very original (not like an anime became mainstreambefore that). I mean seriously I took this up since it was one of my friend's favorite anime, but I just couldn't watch past episode 2, the characters are OK they could be a whole lot better if someone thought the idea through. Overall I can say that I hated the anime and don't plan on starting it again. 3/10

This is one of the most disappointing anime I have ever seen. I saw parts of the animation in an AMV and was pretty fascinated by the dark and gritty designs. After seeing the high ratings i decided to give this show a chance. 
Thirteen episodes later i exclaimed "That's it?!" and was filled with regrets. All the characters are bland tropes and the show has zero interest to give them any development. The setting and Dungeons & Dragon style item and magic system could have been a basis for a great show, but they're only used to provide lame exposition and enanle the bare-bonesself servicing plotline that - spoilers - leads nowhere.


Do yourself a favor, watch the two and a half decently animated fight scenes and skip the rest, because its only there to justify wasting a whole BluRay for this snoozefest.


4/10

This was disappointing. The anime starts with interesting premise, but fails to deliver anything interesting, and doesn't live to its full potential.
The interesting premise is: Imagine "isekai" (transported to another world) anime, where you end up in fantasy world as a .... LICH with a knack for world domination. A dark undead necromancer wizard with tendency towards world domination. Sounds cool, right? It should be awesome, right? right? WRONG.
Most of the time the anime plays with large number of unrelated topics, and ultimately just scraps many of them, forgetting that certain events happened at all. 
In the end I think it'll be mostly interesting toMMO crowd, because it preyty much talks about player remembering past glory days of his favorite guild and trying to protect the guild hall. 


Detailed breakdown is below:

Story:

Story is not good. It is drawn out, feels like it could've been compressed in 6 episodes or less. It ultimately fails to get to any point, and the world is not very interesting by itself. Basically, the anime fails to decide whether the anime world is real or some sort of virtual reality, which ultimately makes the anime less believable. We can have dramatic event at one spot, and then people talking about "NPCs" and "Greater Beings" (i.e. players) in another.


So, it is not good. There was a huge potential regarding malevolent lich character, but it is never realized. Many topics and important events are outright forgotten, that includes whole arcs of the story. There's also sever dissonance in tone of different scenes. Some are relatively light, whil in other scenes heads start flying.


Art:

Average, and sometimes bad. The characters are drawn decently, however, the anime uses very noticeable CG graphics, especially in mass scenes. Those graphics ultimately ruin visuals of the first episode. So, decent, but CG is not good, and ultimately there's nothing to look at.


Sound:

Doesn't really stand out. It is there, but it is not memorable.


Characters:

Majority of characters are cardbord cutouts, and anime doesn't seem to care about any of them. They don't really develop anywhere, and are more like plot devices.


Enjoyment:

I think I wouldn't have lost much if I skipped it completely. I didn't hate it, but I didn't like it either. 


Overall:

Might be worth checking out if you're a fan of MMO, and maybe for the first 2 episodes, which are darker. In all honesty, there are better Isekai anime worth watching.

Story/ we've seen this kind of story numerous times. Some otaku game freak gets trapped in a game and has to find a way out. However that wasn't the case for overlord. We don't know how or why the MC is trapped inside the game. He quickly excepts it without hesitation and barely questions it. He travels around the game in hopes of finding other players who've been trapped to. One thing I noticed about overlord is that it does more telling than showing which leads to a long dialogue of info dumps. Also I don't even think this anime has a story to behonest. I was quite bored after 5 episodes  and zoned out numerous times while watching.  The world building is pretty nice and enjoyed watching the characters travel around. Eventually I grew tired and uninterested so I dropp it. 


Art/ the art in overlord is pretty good I enjoyed the character designs and fight animations. However I noticed that a couple of Shitty CG models were thrown in and they looked atrocious. 


Sound/ overlords sound track really isn't memorable one bit actually it was quite bland to be honest. However I will admit that the opening song was amazing.


Characters/ probably the weakest point of the show. Almost every character in this anime is boring, bland, and uninteresting. Except for the Main Character. Despite him being a annoying Gary Stu I found him to be a rather enjoyable MC. None of the other characters are memorable in any way to the point where I wouldn't have given a damn if they died or not. 


Enjoyment/ despite this anime being extremely unoriginal and somewhat  boring. It was actually pretty enjoyable. It wasn't anything amazing but it wasn't bad either which is why I'm giving this a 5/10.

A short review-- No spoilers
In a Nutshell--An entertaining anime that satisfies your "Bad Ass" character cravings, yet suffers from a plot line that doesn't seem to go anywhere.
Story: 3 This is really disappointing because the anime hints at what COULD be a very interesting plot however, it falls on it's face as you're left with no sense of "direction". The result is you end up "just going along" with the mini-stories constantly waiting for something huge to happen. I felt that the story finally picked up around the final episodes when it was already too late...
Art/Sound: 7 Both the art and sound seemed to fitmy idea of what an MMO should be. The MC constantly looks like a badass, which is fitting for someone who is supposed to be one of the best players in the game. The other characters  also looked nice and were easily distinguishable. 


Characters: 8 Unlike Kirito from SAO, the Overlord aka Momonga, feels like what a seasoned guild master should be. Where Kirito is some kid who can just jump into an MMO and automatically be amazing at everything for NO REASON, our MC is a BADASS because he clearly has spent many many hours with his friends mastering the game in which he is trapped. Because of this, his arrogance is not only acceptable, but WELCOME. I would act the same way if I was thrust into a game where I was the most OP being. The rest of the characters complement each other nicely as well. The voice acting was really well done and draw you into an otherwise boring story.


Enjoyment: 7 This was a hard one to rate. I really enjoyed the "bad ass"  characters and very solid voice acting. The fight scenes were entertaining and always kept me wondering about the true potential of MC's powers.  The downside to this anime is that the story seems erratic and the pacing suffers as well due to there only being 13 episodes.


Overall: 6 This anime gets a 6 which is disappointing because it seemed so promising. The pacing and the shortness of the series costs this anime big time. Otherwise, I really enjoyed watching our badass MC in action against various foes. 


Pros: 

- Good action scenes

- Strong character design 

- Great voice acting

- Barely any fanservice  


Cons

- Plot has pacing issues and doesn't go anywhere until the end

- Series is too short for this type of anime

Just didn't have enough of anything it tried to do for me to keep watching. It tried fan-service, but it was minimal. The story was uninteresting and going nowhere fast; akin to SAO but it doesn't make you care for the main character because even the main character didn't care about the main character before he became overpowered.
That's where the show fails again: the main character being overpowered. 2 shows that have handled this well are One Punch Man, and Dragon Ball.
In Dragon Ball, Goku is always the most powerful, until he's not. His strength is constantly being tested by his opponents and through thatyou get to see progression in his own strength, and the hero overcoming adversity.


In One Punch Man, Saitama is always the most powerful and that's established pretty quickly, much like Overlord. Saitama's power, much like Ainz, is never fully defined, and furthermore, never capped. The place where these two shows differ, is that Saitama is constantly fighting enemies that look like they could one-shot the whole earth, meanwhile, he looks like he's supposed to be working at subway. In Overlord, Ainz looks OP, and acts OP. 


In short:

Goku looks OP, doesn't act OP. (in a sense of being humble)

Saitama looks weak af, and acts weak af. (in a sense of being humble)

Ainz looks OP, and acts OP. 


That's where you fail as a show when you write an OP character. Goku, Saitama, Naruto, and Deku are all fun to watch because they could topple a skyscraper with the flick of a finger, BUT they never act so full of themselves because of it. We get to see these characters coming from a place of weakness and dissatisfaction with their current power; a yearning to get stronger that constantly drives them to improve themselves. 


Therefore, when you write a character wherein the first 3-5 episodes they basically turn on God mode, it becomes about as fun to watch as... actually turning on God mode in a video game. Great for the first 30 minutes; extremely boring afterwards.


What compels me to keep watching Overlord if Ainz is already top tier, owns a castle, and has 2 of the FINEST bitches in the whole show? It's like watching My Hero Academia but Deku's already mastered his quirk, has the whole female cast sucking him, somehow bought the school, and became the #1 hero. Like yeah, it's fun for 3 episodes, until you're like "good for you dude" and move on with your life. I don't need a nigga flexing in my face 24/7. There's a reason the creator of One Punch Man made him live in a 1 bedroom apartment.


TL;DR: If a character has everything he needs, and can get what he wants without the slightest of struggles, it might be fun to watch in some cases, but it's rarely compelling in most. Where's the fun in starting a show at the end?

A show with a protagonist so powerful that nothing can stand in his path, sounds like an interesting concept? Think of it, a guy whose guild of 40+ members worked hard to create the best castle and obtain ultimate items, finds himself trapped in virtual world with all the skills and items he possessed. He's also magician class, thrown into some generic fantasy land full of mediocre and weak creatures. He has also got numerous extremely powerful servants, so does such starting point of an anime or any RPG sound interesting? What is the point of playing a game where you already have dominance?
I've mentionedsome parts of the story in former paragraph, the story is blunt - a guy is trapped in RPG world and tries to protect his place from any possible invaders. He's also scouting around, but that's what I've got from story so far, I've read some reviews and noticed there isn't much of a plot at all.\n
Art and sound are mediocre, though I'd say some character designs don't look appealing at all, especially the protagonist whose design looks pretty bad (why creating such giant cloak, also those two red balls on shoulders which look horrible?).\n
The show falls horribly at characters. The protagonist is typical guy in harem shows, making stupid reactions when a female makes a move to him, for example: *gulp* I...I touched her *loses breath*.  He repeats this every time, and no matter that most of those scenes are supposed to look like jokes, they are just blunt and annoying. Let's move to the servants, they are typical AI, no personality, just responding to the player. They are just talking about the protagonist and how much they love him, though there was a feud between Albedo and Shalltear who will marry the protagonist and give a birth to the heir... which is just.... I almost puked when I watched that scene. Especially since they are undead, so why would he need a heir?? It was just pathetic scene, especially the art and sound were horrible when a character would become obsessed about the protagonist. What about others? I haven't watched much, but I'd say they have barely any role in the show, to let us see the capabilities of protagonist and his servants. They are typically good guys or bad guys, nothing more or less.\n
Now about enjoyment... There wasn't any. All these elements combines heave a pathetic image of a horrible show with no interesting scenes and characters or good points. The whole show is that some bad guys try to do bad stuff to good guys, the protagonist gets involved, the whole drama starts and it's built slowly, the bad guys spend a lot of time summoning their champion which gets destroyed in a blink of an eye. Is the purpose of the show to make us see how ridiculous power of the protagonist is? To see how the servants can be robots who do nothing but obey their master? \n
Overall: the show is annoying, contains only one generic character while others are just some beings who react to the protagonist and have nothing of their own, jokes are overused and blunt, action is boring and done in matter of seconds... Makes me wonder why do people adore this show. \n
I lasted only 4 episodes, I don't know will I ever get enough strength and nerves to watch more to provide more details because this show is just pathetic. \n
If you think of watching the show, I kindly suggest you to skip this rubbish.

The comparisons that people often make to this show and sword art online are for the most part pretty fair, although saying its just as bad or exactly the same as it is going slightly overboard, but really only slightly, the show is still pretty bad for a variety of reasons which I'll discuss but at least somebody who likes this show can confidently say that momonga is less shitty of a character than kirito. Why? Because Kirito is an emo little bitch in spite of being the ultimate Mary Sue(or since he's a guy Gary Stu) and having an army of anime bitches thatwant to hop on his dick, the dudes got no reason to be depressed all the time. 


Kirito also had no reason why he should be so overpowered, he played solo a good portion of the time, used leveling tactics that he admitted were ineffective, and the beta test only gave him 6 months more time with the game than non-beta testers and no advantage over other beta testers, in sword art online its also mentioned that some of the mechanics had changed since beta so there was no reason why it would have given him the kind of omniscience he seems to possess with regards to the game. 


Momonga and Kirito have in common that they are overpowered, but with momonga it actually makes sense for him to be so powerful: he played the game for years, probably from its initial release of its peak in popularity up until the point the servers shut down, in any case long enough to reach maximum level, him and his guild had also collected items from all over the game's world and he kept all the items his comrades left behind. 


The MMO world of Overlord also makes more sense than that of Sword Art Online's... at least from what I've gathered from watching these 13 episodes they make sense, in Sword Art Online, its as if the writer had never played an MMO himself. 


Unfortunately having a protagonist who is less insuferable than kirito and having a fictional world that actually makes sense because it sticks to its own rules dosen't make for a good show on its own, the NPCs are still pretty flat because they don't really have notworthy personality traits other than admiration for momonga and the other MMO neckbeards they've mistaken for gods, the show's pacing is bogged down by its need to explain everything in excessive detail and bombard you with other kinds of useless information.


 I couldn't help but be a little annoyed with the fact that the show gave momonga's first party so much screen time and then killed them off, and this wasn't even due to any attatchment I had to these characters that i was annoyed, it was just annoying that the show wasted my time with these characters that didn't really serve a purpose.


I consider the show to be of poor quality but at least I didn't feel like it completely wasted my time, only mostly wasted it which is why I give it a 4 rather than something lower

Sit down kids, I'll tell you the tale of "Overlord", also known as "I've wasted 6 hours watching this shit but I don't feel nor good nor bad about it."
I'm not going to write a long review, it's not worth, really. Simply put: Overlord has an amazing premise. A really cool looking, overpowered, lich lord, with all the power in the world, ready to explore and very possibly conquer a completely new world, with his overpowered followers? FUCK, looks great. And for the first episodes after the first two (they acted as a setup) it was! Ainz (Or Momon, however ya wanna call him), reallygave the impression of the overpowered, godtier guy and it was done well, giving me a boner whenever he showed how great his power was.

But then...eh.

I started to realize, episode by episode, how the anime is overall bland: the protagonist (again, he is probably the most powerful being in the world and he knows that), spends his time being the insecure idiot-smartass that he is, """exploring""" his new surroundings and defending himself from fucking worms that can't hurt him anyway (why he is even worried about them?) while his followers, who are all bland characters with no interesting personality, do stuff for him. The premise of this godtier being destroying and conquering everything is soon gone by episode 6, and falls even more as the writer puts some bullshit to make stuff more spicy ("OH MY GOD X IS BEING MIND CONTROLLED BY SOMEBODY FOR NO REASON AT ALL I AM SO WORRIED ABOUT IT AND I SPEND TWO EPISODES FIGHTING X ALTHOUGH THE FIGHT COULD'VE ENDED IN THREE SECONDS WOW"). To top it off, there are even more useless characters and at the end of the anime the protagonist walks out of a tavern saying some bullshit like "GUYS GET READY OMG DIS GON BE BIG" to characters that we don't know just to hype us up. Well, I'm not hyped. I'm disgusted that a character that looked like he was going to be GREAT ended up being meh. And that's the worst kind of disappointment: I couldn't see the bullshit at first, and ended up wasting precious time on it because of this cool looking skeleton guy.


Sigh.


6/10 and I'm being generous.

This anime is boring! So-so boring!
Protagonist don't face challenges or struggles whatsoever.
Not only the strongest human fighters can't even scratch him or even his guardians, but you can also ressurect others in this world. 
The only enemy that could actually damage protagonist (Opening spoilered her, BTW), was standing ABSOLUTELY still, that allowed Momonga to prepare however he liked before battle. 
Love line is don't exist, both love interests simply fighting over him. 
Protagonist don't know what he wants. "I sorta gonna kill you, because you sorta pissed me off".
We can't even see the real him, because the world tones him down.
Who thought that would bea great idea, when protagonist can't even act like a human, that he is?


Oh, but he is great! Every two minutes someone tells, how great he is.

Everyone just shove Momonga in my throat. 

Not let me judge by his actions, no! He is great, deal with it! 


And he isn't even that great!
